1 JULY.part4: Blessed is the man to whom the Lord will not impute sin.
1 JULY.part5:
Who is a blessed man? The man who is blessed is truly happy. This is because the Lord will not impute his sin to him. The word "impute" means to attribute or "put on his account". "Not to impute sin" means his sins are not counted and no charges are laid against him even though he deserves it. But how is that possible? Did the Bible not say "The soul that sinneth, it shall die" [Ezekiel 18:20a] and "The wages of sin is death" [Romans 6:23a]? The remuneration for sin is death. Sin offers temporal pleasure but exacts a heavy price of guilt and misery. Sin drives us by the lust of the flesh, the lust of the eyes and the pride of life. It tempts, deceives and ensnares us to face God's wrath. Every sin committed actively in disobedience or passively in defiance will be punished. Ultimately sin requires of every sinner the highest price - death and eternal separation from God in hell. Hebrews 9:27 says, "And as it is appointed unto men once to die, but after this the judgment". This is the bad news.

But there is hope for the sinner if he realizes how heinous sin is and flees to one who can save. Jesus Christ the sinless God-Man came into the world to save sinners. On the cross He shed His precious blood and opened the only way for sinners to be reconciled to God. This is the Gospel, the good news of sins forgiven and life everlasting given to everyone who truly turns from the way of sin to Christ. Blessed is this man who has heard and responded to this for his sins are not imputed to him. Have you?
1 JULY.part7: For Christ also hath once suffered for sins, the just for the unjust, that he might bring us to God, being put to death in the flesh, but quickened by the Spirit. - 1 Peter 3:18.

2 JULY.part4: Blessed is the man to whom the Lord will not impute sin.
2 JULY.part5:
The theological doctrine of imputation is the vicarious attribution of sin, guilt, or righteousness of a person to another. On one hand, through the sin of Adam, sin and death were imputed to all men - "Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned" [Romans 5:12]. On the other, through the atoning death of Christ on the cross, righteousness came upon many - " ... much more the grace of God, and the gift by grace, which is by one man, Jesus Christ, hath abounded unto many" [Romans 5:15b].

By imputation we see how a sinner is forgiven of his sins and receives salvation by grace through faith in the Lord Jesus Christ. This is how it works. The hearing of God's Word convicts of sin and produces faith in sinners to turn to Christ for forgiveness and saving grace. This is the essence of salvation wrought in Christ Jesus. When I trust Him to be my Saviour, He takes my sins upon Himself and clothes me with His righteousness. My sins are imputed to Christ and His righteousness imputed to me. The sinless Son of God took my sins and His righteousness became mine so I can now stand justified before God the Father. "For Christ also hath once suffered for sins, the just for the unjust, that He might bring us to God" [1 Peter 3:18a].

The doctrine of imputation is realized and effected in the substitutionary death of the Lord Jesus for our sins. This truth should fill our hearts with awe and gratitude to surrender our lives to God and wholeheartedly worship Him.
2 JULY.part7: For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so by the obedience of one shall many be made righteous. - Romans 5:19

3 JULY.part4: Cometh this blessedness then upon the circumcision only, or upon the uncircumcision also? for we say that faith was reckoned to Abraham for righteousness.
3 JULY.part5:
The question is asked here whether the blessing of forgiveness of sin is available only to the circumcised (the mark of Israel as God's chosen people) or also to all peoples even uncircumcised Gentiles (non-Jews). The answer - it is available to all, both Jews and Gentiles. In Genesis 12:3 when God called Abram to leave Ur, God promised to bless him. "And I will bless them that bless thee, and curse him that curseth thee: and in thee shall all families of the earth be blessed". "In thee shall all the families of the earth" speaks of God's purpose that the blessings of salvation through the Gospel of Jesus Christ is for all the world. It is clear from God's Word to Ananias concerning Paul's calling to apostleship in Act 9:15b: " ... he is a chosen vessel unto me, to bear my name before the Gentiles, and kings, and the children of Israel." Moreover, Paul himself said "Whereunto I am ordained a preacher, and an apostle, ... a teacher of the Gentiles in faith and verity" [1 Timothy 2:7].

The scope of our Gospel ministry is the people in the world. The challenge for us is to go into all the world and preach the Gospel in obedience to the Great Commission of our Lord in Matthew 28:18-20. When was the last time you witnessed to someone that Jesus Christ came to save them? Truly, the harvest is plenteous but the labourers are few. Will you pray for them and tell them the Gospel so they might be saved by grace and enjoy this eternal blessedness? May the love of God constrain us.
3 JULY.part7: For I am not ashamed of the Gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek. - Romans 1:16

4 JULY.part4: Cometh this blessedness then upon the circumcision only, or upon the uncircumcision also? for we say that faith was reckoned to Abraham for righteousness.
4 JULY.part5:
When was Abraham's faith in God counted to him for righteousness? At what point did Abraham believe and was saved? Was it when he was circumcised? Did circumcision save him? The answer is vital because the Jews in the New Testament believed that circumcision is equivalent to salvation. While it is true that circumcision was a unique mark that set the Jews apart from all others as God's people, it could not save them because physical circumcision could not bring about the change of heart that only faith in God could.

This is precisely how Abraham was saved by his faith in God. Before his circumcision, he was already declared righteous. This is validated by the chronology of events. Abraham was first given God's covenant promise when he was 75 years old [Genesis 12:1-4]. In Genesis 15:6, just before Ishmael was born, Abraham believed in the LORD and He counted it to him for righteousness. Genesis 16:16 informs that Abraham was 86 years old when Ishmael was born. And at 99, Abraham was circumcised ... fourteen years after he was declared righteous by God [Genesis 17:24].

Today the same truth applies. Circumcision in the Old Testament points towards the sacrament of Baptism in the New Testament. Like circumcision, baptism cannot save. Faith alone in Jesus Christ saves. Why then be baptized if you have already put your faith in Christ as your Lord and Saviour? Well, true faith obeys God's Word by submitting to Christ and confessing Him publicly through Baptism that you belong to Him. This clarifies that a person is saved and the significance of Baptism. Having received Christ, are you baptized?
4 JULY.part7: Whosoever therefore shall be ashamed of me and of my words in this adulterous and sinful generation; of him also shall the Son of man be ashamed, when he cometh in the glory of his Father with the holy angels. - Mark 8:38

5 JULY.part4: How was it then reckoned? when he was in circumcision, or in uncircumcision? Not in circumcision, but in uncircumcision.
5 JULY.part5:
Regarding when Abraham was saved, Genesis 15:6 tells us when Abraham believed in the LORD, it was counted to him for righteousness. That took place some fourteen years before Abraham's circumcision [Genesis 17:24] and many more years before God's Law was given at Mt Sinai. How then was Abraham saved? There were yet no Ten Commandments for him to keep. Therefore it cannot be said that Abraham was saved by keeping the Law.

Salvation is not by means of trying to keep God's Law. The Law of God reflects the pure holiness of God and no one can keep it. The Law convicts sinners of their sin and their desperate need to flee to the Saviour because only Christ kept God's Law perfectly. Yet man in his spiritual blindness and pride boasts he can earn the merit of God's favour by doing good. Abraham was saved by faith in the promises of God before the Law (the Decalogue) and before circumcision. Abraham believed the covenant promises of God by grace in Genesis 12:1-4. "He staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief; but was strong in faith, giving glory to God; and being fully persuaded that, what he had promised, he was able also to perform" [Romans 4:20-21].

Abraham was saved exactly in the way we read in Ephesians 2:8 - "For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast." How were you saved? By grace or by good works? Did your belief that the Lord Jesus died for your sins humble you to repentance and trust only in Him?
5 JULY.part7: That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved. - Romans 10:9

6 JULY.part4: And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had yet being uncircumcised: that he might be the father of all them that believe, though they be not circumcised; that righteousness might be imputed unto them also.
6 JULY.part5:
The intent of Paul in Romans 4 is to prove the doctrine of salvation by faith from the Old Testament. To do that, Paul appealed to two prominent Old Testament personages in Jewish history - Abraham [v. 1-5] and David [v. 6-8]. If Paul could show that Abraham was counted righteous by God through faith [Romans 4:3], the Apostle would have proven the doctrine of salvation by grace. The doctrine, however, begs the question - why then did God give Abraham the sign of circumcision? What is the point of circumcision, or in our context, water baptism?

Verse 11 contains two important words - "sign" and "seal". Circumcision is a God-given sign, as is the New Testament sacrament of water baptism. A sign has a two-fold purpose. First, a sign and the thing signified are closely related, but the thing signified is always greater than the sign itself. For example, on the way to the airport, you see a sign that reads "Airport 10 kilometres". The sign is not the airport, but it points to the thing signified - the airport. In other words, circumcision points to something greater and more significant, namely the covenant that God established with Abraham on account of what Christ's atoning work did.

Second, a sign can also indicate ownership. In Levitical law, when a Hebrew servant expressed his desire to serve his master for life, the master would pierce the ear of the servant with an aul [Exodus 21:6]. The servant's pierced ear is a sign of ownership by his master. In the same manner, New Testament baptism - like Old Testament circumcision - marks the believer's identity with and ownership by Christ. Baptism is a way for believers to testify to the world that they now belong to Christ.
6 JULY.part7: For ye are bought with a price: therefore glorify God in your body, and in your spirit, which are God's. - 1 Corinthians 6:20

7 JULY.part4: And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had yet being uncircumcised: that he might be the father of all them that believe, though they be not circumcised; that righteousness might be imputed unto them also.
7 JULY.part5:
Old Testament circumcision and New Testament baptism are covenantal signs; they are also the "seal of the righteousness of the faith". In the past, when kings and emperors issued decrees, they marked them with a royal seal, usually a signet ring. The seal served two purposes - to authorize and authenticate. First, when an emperor used a seal, it gave personal authority to the decree, like his signature. Today, seals are used in travel documents such as passports and visas, indicating that the issuing authority stands behind the person who carries that document. Second, a seal also serves the function of a notary public. When copies of a document have the seal "certified true", it validates the authenticity of the copies.

Sacraments work the same way. In Abraham's case, Paul makes the point that the sign of circumcision was "a seal of the righteousness of the faith", which God gave to Abraham after "he believed in the LORD; and [God] counted it to him for righteousness" [Genesis 15:6]. Note the nature and timing of the seal. Circumcision was a seal confirming not only the sincerity of Abraham's faith, but also the righteousness imputed to him. This is also seen in the timing of circumcision. Abraham was circumcised after he believed the LORD [Genesis 15:6; 17:10-11], proving he was not justified by his circumcision, but by the righteousness imputed to him before he was circumcised. The New Testament sacrament of baptism works the same way. It marks the baptised person's identity with Christ. Abraham became the proto-example of "all them that believe" - Jews and Gentiles. And Abraham became the "father" of all believers not because he was the author of our faith but because we have the same kind of faith as he did.
7 JULY.part7: Have you been baptised? Baptism does not save, but it marks your commitment to and identity with Christ.

8 JULY.part4: And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had yet being uncircumcised: that he might be the father of all them that believe, though they be not circumcised; that righteousness might be imputed unto them also.
8 JULY.part5:
Abraham was one of the first two names to be mentioned in Matthew's genealogy of our Lord Jesus. "The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham." [Matthew 1:1]. He was also given the most space in the Hall of Faith - twelve out of forty verses [Hebrews 11:8-19]. It is for good reason that Paul gave him the title - "the father of all them that believe". In James, he was called the "Friend of God" [James 2:23]. If there is one sentence to describe Abraham, it would be that "he was a man of faith".

When Abraham left his home in Ur of the Chaldees to move to a land that he did not know and had never seen, he was not suffering from mid-life crisis [Genesis 12:1-9]. He "obeyed; and went out, not knowing whither he went" [Hebrews 11:8]. Abraham was already 75 years old when he began his journey of faith with the one true God.

Ur of the Chaldees was one of the earliest civilizations in the world. For Abraham to move out of Ur to another place would be like you moving from Singapore to a place you have never heard of. He was exchanging life in an urban city for a nomad's life, living in tents [Hebrews 11:9]. It also meant Abraham was leaving the religion he had been raised in - an idol-worshipping religion [Joshua 24:2] - to embrace a God of whom he had never heard. That is faith.

In Genesis 15, God promised Abraham the son "that shall come forth out of thine own bowels shall be thine heir" [Genesis 15:4-6]. For a man well past his prime, believing that is faith. Abraham's faith is a great reminder that it is never too late to submit to God's plan for your life!
8 JULY.part7: Faith is to take hold of God's promise and resting wholly in Him.

9 JULY.part4: And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had yet being uncircumcised: that he might be the father of all them that believe, though they be not circumcised; that righteousness might be imputed unto them also.
9 JULY.part5:
When Abraham was 75 years old, God promised him that he would be a blessing to all the families of the earth [Genesis 12:3]. Some years later, God promised Abraham that his seed would be as numerous as the stars in the sky [Genesis 15:5]. When Abraham was 99 years old, God again promised that nations and kings would come from him, and God established an everlasting covenant with him [Genesis 17:6-8].

It was only 25 years after leaving Ur, when he was 100 years old, that Abraham saw the fulfilment of God's promises. That is faith - one that Paul says "staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief; but was strong in faith, giving glory to God" [Romans 4:20].

When Paul said that Abraham was "the father of all them that believe, though they were not circumcised", he did not mean that no one before Abraham was saved. Paul meant by those words that through the faith of Abraham, the way of salvation was made explicitly clear for the first time - that salvation comes by faith in God. Abraham showed what it was to have faith, and he became the father of all who believe. Thus, every believer - Jew and Gentile - can trace our spiritual ancestry to God.

What an ancestry that is. The writer of Hebrews reminds us that we "are compassed about with so great a cloud of witnesses" [Hebrews 12:1a]. What privileged company we will be in when we get to heaven - some circumcised, many are not, but all saved by the faith as that of Abraham. Having this promise therefore, "let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us" [Hebrews 12:1b].
9 JULY.part7: Humble yourself before Christ, and you will find yourself in exalted company.

10 JULY.part4: And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had yet being uncircumcised: that he might be the father of all them that believe, though they be not circumcised; that righteousness might be imputed unto them also.
10 JULY.part5:
Having made a covenant with Abraham, some years later, God sealed that covenant with the sign of circumcision. In ancient times, most covenants would have the following elements - preamble identifying the parties of the covenant [Genesis 17:1], promise and provision [Genesis 17:6-7], sanctions [Genesis 17:14], and period [Genesis 17:7-8]. For Abraham and the Israelites, the sign of circumcision reminded them of the indispensable response required of those who bore the sign. The covenantal sign has a vertical dimension. It marks the person as coming under the authority of God, being in subjection to His commandments. It also has a horizontal dimension, pointing to the communal aspect of the covenant. Receiving the sign made one a part of the Abrahamic family, the covenantal community of faith. The special blessings which accompany the covenant are only available to those who bear the covenantal sign; those without the sign are "cut off " [Genesis 17:14].

In the Old Testament, circumcision was never to be regarded as a mere physical act. Moses gave this solemn reminder to the children of Israel, "Circumcise therefore the foreskin of your heart, and be no more stiffnecked" (Deuteronomy 10:16; Jeremiah 4:4). The outward sign (Old Testament circumcision and New Testament baptism) is never to be considered apart from an inward reality (read Romans 2:28-29; 9:6-8). Above all, the covenantal sign is a mark of consecration. To be circumcised - an act of obedience in itself - marks one as being whole-heartedly dedicated to God [Deuteronomy 30:6]. Just as God called Israel to keep the covenant, so likewise we - as the people of God - are called to continue in commitment, loyalty, trust and obedience to Him.
10 JULY.part7: The key thing God is after is our commitment to Him. "Thou shalt keep my covenant ... This is my covenant ..." [Genesis 17:9-10].

11 JULY.part4: And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had yet being uncircumcised: that he might be the father of all them that believe, though they be not circumcised; that righteousness might be imputed unto them also.
11 JULY.part5:
Circumcision, the covenantal sign in the Old Testament, is replaced by baptism in the New Testament. The Westminster Confession of Faith teaches that "Sacraments are holy signs and seals of the covenant of grace, immediately instituted by God, to represent Christ and His benefits, and to confirm our interest in Him; as also to put a visible difference between those that belong unto the church and the rest of the world; and solemnly to engage them to the service of God in Christ, according to His Word" (Chapter 27.1).

The sacrament of baptism is a sign not in the sense that it is a miracle of sorts (cf. John 2:11). There is nothing supernatural in the administration of the sacraments. Baptism is a sign in that it points to some thing beyond the act. In other words, baptism is not redemption in Christ, but it points to the reality of Christ's redemption.

In warning the Jews against placing their confidence in circumcision, Paul said that just because they were circumcised did not mean they were saved (Romans 2:28-29). Likewise, the outward sign of baptism is not to be equated with the inward regeneration of the heart. The external rite is not a guarantee of internal regeneration. If baptism does not save, why then do we insist on it? First, baptism is God's command, which we must obey. Second, baptism initiates us into a local church in which we must serve and worship. Third, it marks us as separating ourselves unto God from the world to which we are a light bearing the testimony of our Lord Jesus.
11 JULY.part7: While saving grace is not conferred by the act of baptism, A.A. Hodge says that baptism is "a visible sign of our covenant to be the Lord's and devoted to His service ... it is a public profession of our faith into the Christian Church, and a symbol of our union with our fellow-Christians."

12 JULY.part4: And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had yet being uncircumcised: that he might be the father of all them that believe, though they be not circumcised; that righteousness might be imputed unto them also.
12 JULY.part5:
Baptism, as a sacrament, is also a seal of God's promise. The word seal is derived from the practice of formalizing documents. In ancient times, when a contract was made or when the king passed a decree, a small amount of wax was melted on the document and a seal affixed. If it was a decree, the seal would be the king's signet ring. The seal proved the authenticity of the document. Even today, seals are used on important documents, such as diplomas, marriage certificates, etc.

Just as the sign of baptism is not a miraculous act, so the seal of baptism does not make regeneration a reality for the baptised person. Just like a person who has never attended school but buys a diploma off the internet, possession of that piece of paper does not make him a graduate.

Baptism as a seal is a promise to the true believer that he is saved by God's grace alone and through faith alone. And as surely as he has been baptised by water, he can be certain his sins have been cleansed by the precious blood of our Lord Jesus Christ. Water baptism does not do this, but it testifies to the believer the reality of saving grace.

The real seal is the Holy Spirit. When the Spirit seals us inwardly, God puts His stamp of ownership upon us which indicates that we belong to Him and nothing can change that ownership. This inward seal is signified by the outward sign of baptism. Thus the sacraments - water baptism and the Lord's Supper - are signs and seals of the veracity of God's promises.
12 JULY.part7: Christ has "sealed us, and given the earnest of the Spirit in our hearts" [2 Corinthians 1:21-22].

13 JULY.part4: And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had yet being uncircumcised: that he might be the father of all them that believe, though they be not circumcised; that righteousness might be imputed unto them also.
13 JULY.part5:
When God called Abraham out of the Ur of the Chaldees to a land which He had reserved for him, God gave the promise not only to Abraham but also his children [Genesis 12:7; 13:15-16]. God would seal the covenant with circumcision, the sign that the covenant applied not just to Abraham alone but also to every male child in his household [Genesis 17:7-10]. God said, "He that is eight days old shall be circumcised among you, every man child in your generations ..." [Genesis 17:12].

While both the sons of Abraham - Ishmael and Isaac - were circumcised [Genesis 17:25], a distinction is made between them. "God said unto Abraham ... in Isaac shall thy seed be called" [Genesis 21:12]. This simply means that while God's covenant relationships extended beyond Abraham to his family, with circumcision being the sign of the covenant, not all who were circumcised belonged to the seed of Abraham. Paul made this clear - "For they are not all Israel, which are of Israel: Neither, because they are the seed of Abraham, are they all children: but, in Isaac shall thy seed be called" [Romans 9:6-7].

The same idea applies to infant baptism. It is a sign given to believing parents because God has always dealt with His people through covenant relationships. When children are baptised, it is not an indication they are saved. It also does not mean their salvation is necessarily assured in the future.

When parents present their infants for baptism, it is a consecration of the hands and heart and a promise on the part of the parents to nurture the child in the ways of God. In the baptism of our children - who are the "heritage of the LORD" - God asks us not simply to trust Him, but to remember that He trusts us with His very own.
13 JULY.part7: Lo, children are an heritage of the LORD: And the fruit of the womb is his reward. - Psalm 127:3

14 JULY.part4: And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had yet being uncircumcised: that he might be the father of all them that believe, though they be not circumcised; that righteousness might be imputed unto them also.
14 JULY.part5:
Presbyterians have been accused of - wrongfully - baptising infants. That is an inaccurate and misleading statement. Presbyterians baptise two groups of people - adults who have confessed Christ as their Saviour and children of Christians. The Westminster Confession of Faith teaches "Not only those that do actually profess faith in and obedience unto Christ, but also the infants of one or both believing parents, are to be baptized" (Chapter 28.4).

Abraham believed, and the LORD counted it to him for righteousness. Then, the covenantal sign - circumcision - was given. Abraham was circumcised when he was 99 years old; Ishmael was circumcised when he was 13. Isaac was circumcised at eight days old. What was the spiritual status of Ishmael and Isaac when they were circumcised? They were children of Abraham who believed God. So, on account of Abraham's faith, God entered into a covenant with Abraham's children. In other words, a believer's children are included in the covenant on the basis of the believer's faith.

Presbyterians believe in the continuity of the covenant of grace in the Old and New Testaments, meaning that the covenant is an "everlasting covenant" [Genesis 17:13; Hebrews 13:20]. So while the covenantal sign has changed from circumcision to baptism, the administration of the covenant has not. When God said to Abraham, "This is my covenant ... between me and you and thy seed after thee; every man child among you shall be circumcised" [Genesis 17:9-10]. The principle of "you and thy seed" continues in the new administration. In the baptism of children, they are marked out as God's property, assuring Christian parents that the covenant God has made with them is also made with their children.
14 JULY.part7: For the promise is unto you, and to your children, and to all that are afar off, even as many as the Lord our God shall call. - Acts 2:39

15 JULY.part2: First Step - The Obedience of Faith
15 JULY.part4: And the father of circumcision to them who are not of the circumcision only, but who also walk in the steps of that faith of our father Abraham, which he had being yet uncircumcised.
15 JULY.part5:
In his commentary, The Epistle to the Romans, Scottish theologian, John Murray (1898-1975) describes Abraham as the leader of the faithful, adding that "we walk, not abreast, but in file, following in the footprints left by Abraham." The Christian life is a pilgrimage. We who come later walk in the footsteps of those who have gone before us; at the same time, we leave our footprints of faith for those that will come after us. And we are all heading in the same direction.

Abram was an idol-worshipper [Joshua 24:2]. Like all sinners, Abram did not have any interest in, nor was he seeking the living and true God. It was God who called Abram to leave Ur of the Chaldees [Genesis 12:1], and he "obeyed; and he went out, not knowing whither he went" [Hebrews 11:8].

The initiative of faith coming from God is clearly shown in Genesis 12 - "I will shew thee (a land) ... I will make of thee a great nation ... I will bless thee ... (I will) make thy name great ... I will bless them that bless thee ... (I will) curse him that curseth thee ... unto thy seed will I give this land" [Genesis 12:1-7]. Abram did nothing to deserve God's blessings.

God called Abram, and Abram responded to God's calling in obedience. In modern evangelism, especially at altar calls during Gospel meetings, the preacher appeals to the congregation "to decide for Jesus" or "to let Jesus come into your heart" implying that it is the sinner who does the work of believing so that God will save him. But that turns the Gospel of grace on its head.

To have faith in God is simply to obey Him. If you are not a believer, God is calling sinners to Himself. In response, they are to obey in faith.
15 JULY.part7: Abraham "obeyed; and he went out, not knowing whither he went" [Hebrews 11:8]. Faith is obedience to God's calling.

16 JULY.part2: Second Step - The Pilgrimage of Faith
16 JULY.part4: And the father of circumcision to them who are not of the circumcision only, but who also walk in the steps of that faith of our father Abraham, which he had being yet uncircumcised.
16 JULY.part5:
In obeying the call of God, Abram exchanged his life as an urbanite for that of a pilgrim. After leaving Ur of the Chaldees, Abram followed the route of the Fertile Crescent, heading in a north-westerly direction to Haran [Genesis 12:5] before heading south toward Shechem [Genesis 12:6]. Even when he finally settled in the land of promise, Abraham considered himself to be "in a strange country, dwelling in tabernacles with Isaac and Jacob, the heirs with him of the same promise: he looked for a city which hath foundations, whose builder and maker is God" [Hebrews 11:9-10]. Abraham remained a pilgrim. He never considered Canaan his final destination.

Like Abraham, our life on earth is a pilgrimage of faith - a walk [Galatians 5:25; Ephesians 2:10; 4:1]. We enter the strait gate and walk the narrow way [Matthew 7:13-14]. The thinking that when a sinner is saved, he is no longer a pilgrim is wrong. In fact, the pilgrimage of faith begins at our conversion. Christians are pilgrims. And we ought to live like pilgrims.

This means we must leave what we are comfortable with and the things we have grown up in, namely the world and all its trappings. We are to leave the past to follow Christ. God called Abram out of Ur, and he departed [Genesis 12:4]. Our Lord Jesus says to Peter and Andrew, "Follow me, and I will make you fishers of men. And they straightway left their nets ..." [Matthew 4:19-20a]. That was the start of their pilgrimage of faith. That must also be your experience in your pilgrimage of faith. Have you left? What have you left? What are you still hanging on to?
16 JULY.part7: I have decided to follow Jesus. The world behind me, the cross before me. No turning back, no turning back. - Sadhu Sundar Singh

17 JULY.part2: Third Step - The Object of Faith
17 JULY.part4: And the father of circumcision to them who are not of the circumcision only, but who also walk in the steps of that faith of our father Abraham, which he had being yet uncircumcised.
17 JULY.part5:
God called Abraham out of Ur of the Chaldees, and he "obeyed ... went out, not knowing whither he went" [Hebrews 11:8]. It may seem Abram was stepping out into the dark, but that is not the case. Abraham did not leave his home in Ur to be a vagrant. God gave this assurance to Abraham, "Get thee out of thy country ... unto a land that I will shew thee" [Genesis 12:1].

Likewise, faith is not a leap into the unknown. The value of faith is only as good as the object of that faith. And the object of the Christian's faith is our Lord Jesus Christ. Christ called Peter and Andrew, "Follow me, and I will make you fishers of men. And they straightway left their nets, and followed Him" [Matthew 4:19-20]. Christ called Matthew, "Follow me. And he arose, and followed Him" [Matthew 9:9].

That is the essence of discipleship. The basis for discipleship is faith [John 2:11]. The mark of discipleship is to hold on to the words of Christ; "If ye continue in My word, then are ye My disciples indeed" [John 8:31]. The expression of discipleship is obedience to Jesus' command to "love one another" [John 13:34-35]. The goal of discipleship is to be like Christ, to do what He did. He washed the feet of His disciples as an example of humility for us to follow [John 13:15]. Our Lord Jesus "went about all the cities and villages ... preaching the gospel of the kingdom" [Matthew 9:35], and He has given us the Great Commission to do likewise - to "go ye into all the world, and preach the Gospel to every creature" [Mark 16:15].

Is there evidence of discipleship in your life?
17 JULY.part7: Be ye followers of me, even as I also am of Christ. - 1 Corinthians 11:1.

18 JULY.part4: And the father of circumcision to them who are not of the circumcision only, but who also walk in the steps of that faith of our father Abraham, which he had being yet uncircumcised.
18 JULY.part5:
God promised He would show Abraham the land where he should go. God also promised this land would be inhabited by Abraham's descendants who would be as numerous as the stars in the sky [Genesis 15:5]. When Abraham left Ur, he was seventy-five years old. However for another decade, Sarah remained childless. With every passing day, the promise of a son was fading. Sarah's childlessness because of age was not only a biological problem, it also posed a spiritual conundrum.

So, the ageing couple took matters into their own hands. Twenty-six years after leaving Ur, Abraham finally had his first son, Ishmael, through his Egyptian handmaid, Hagar [Genesis 16:1]. But Ishmael was not the son of promise. God told Abraham that the heir must "come forth out of (his) own bowels" [Genesis 15:4]. The son of promise must come from the father of faith.

If Abraham and Sarah were to have a son, it would have to be a miracle from God. Finally, at ninety years of age, Sarah gave birth to a son "when she was past age, because she judged Him faithful who had promised" [Hebrews 11:11]. Abraham also believed, who "against hope believed in hope ... staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief; but was strong in faith ... being fully persuaded that, what He had promised, He was able also to perform" [Romans 4:18-21].

Abraham and Sarah are the supreme examples of faith. Likely, your situation is different from theirs. Sarah believed God to be faithful. Abraham was fully persuaded God was able to do as He promised. And so should we. The essence and the exercise of our faith should not be any different because the God of Abraham and Sarah is also our God.

Do you have a faith like Abraham's?
18 JULY.part7: If we believe not, yet He abideth faithful: (God) cannot deny Himself. - 2 Timothy 2:13

19 JULY.part4: And the father of circumcision to them who are not of the circumcision only, but who also walk in the steps of that faith of our father Abraham, which he had being yet uncircumcised.
19 JULY.part5:
Abraham loved Isaac dearly because he came late in Abraham's life. Abraham believed God's promise despite seemingly impossible odds. Abraham's faith would be tested again when God asked him to offer Isaac for a burnt offering [Genesis 22:2]. This was a test of Abraham's obedience to and love for God. Some have speculated that perhaps - Isaac being the son of his old age - Abraham had endeared himself so much to Isaac that he had taken over the place of God in Abraham's life.

God's test for Abraham was a spiritual one, and it would prove whether he would continue to have faith in and obey God. In this test, Abraham must choose between obeying God's command (to offer Isaac as a burnt offering) and believing God's promise (that Isaac would be the heir from whom all blessings would come). This was the spiritual dilemma facing Abraham: God had promised him his descendants would come from Isaac. Now God was commanding him to sacrifice his son.

Abraham faced a Catch-22 situation. However, his faith in God for the gift of a son (after some 25 years) proved God was not only immutable; He is also the God of the impossible. From a human standpoint, this conundrum could not be resolved. And although Abraham could not see any way out of it, he believed that God had the answer, and so he obeyed.

What was the basis of Abraham's obedience? Abraham obeyed God's command because of what he knew about God. Abraham believed and obeyed God even though he did not know the way out of this seemingly impossible situation.
19 JULY.part7: Look to God and assess your circumstance based on what you know about Him, and then obey.

20 JULY.part4: For the promise, that he should be the heir of the world, was not to Abraham, or to his seed, through the law, but through the righteousness of faith. For if they which are of the law be heirs, faith is made void, and the promise made of none effect.
20 JULY.part5:
Paul had been defending the doctrine of grace by dispelling the errors of salvation by works, teaching that "Abraham believed God, and it was counted unto him for righteousness" [v. 3], the error of salvation by rites, namely circumcision, making the point that Abraham was counted righteous "not in circumcision, but in uncircumcision" [v. 10].

In Romans 4:13, Paul would dispel the notion of salvation by keeping the law. The sign of circumcision was given some 14 years after Abraham believed. The law was given even later, over four centuries later. This meant that circumcision and the law had nothing to do with Abraham being counted righteous. It also meant that neither the rite nor the law replaced the covenant that God had made with Abraham. This was Paul's argument to the Galatians.

Paul also pointed out the futility of keeping the law to earn our righteousness. The Law, by its definition, is contrary to faith. The Law sets a standard by which a man's actions are measured. The Law also demanded volitional obedience - an act on the part of the one observing it. The Law is established so that we may keep it, and thus, failure to do so incurs wrath. If salvation could be earned by keeping the law, then our salvation rests in our hands. If we believe we have kept enough of the law, then God is obliged to save us.

But that goes against the doctrine of grace. We are not saved by the law but by grace through faith [Ephesians 2:8]. And faith is believing obedience.
20 JULY.part7: Law and religious rituals are enemies of grace.

21 JULY.part4: For if they which are of the law be heirs, faith is made void, and the promise made of none effect.
21 JULY.part5:
Faith and law are diametrically opposed. It is either faith or law, and neither the twain shall mix. If you choose one, you naturally reject the other. The law focuses on what man must do. Faith on the other hand, emphasises what God has accomplished. If salvation comes by way of our own efforts, it also means we will not be trusting God. And if we believe salvation is by faith in what God has done, then it cannot be earned by our works. In that sense, law is made void by faith, and faith is made void by law.

Another result of trusting in our own efforts for salvation is that the "promise (is) made of none effect" [v. 14]. The phrase "made of none effect" means "to be rendered useless". It is used to describe the ground in which the fig tree that bore no fruit stood [Luke 13:7]. In Romans 4:14, Paul uses the phrase to point out that human efforts nullify God's grace and His promise of salvation. How so? If salvation depended on our keeping the law, then God's promise of salvation is conditional, meaning if we keep the law, then God promises to save us. But the Word of God states clearly that "by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified in His sight" [Romans 3:20], which means no sinner will be saved, and in turn means God's promise is worthless.

This truth is seen in Christ's dealing with the woman caught in adultery. By her actions, she had failed to keep the law. She deserved God's condemnation. But our Lord Jesus said to her, "Neither do I condemn thee: go, and sin no more" [John 8:11]. Her salvation was not based on what she would have to do (sin no more) but on Christ's promise.
21 JULY.part7: If the promise [of salvation] is through the medium of the law ... there would have been no promise at all; it would have been no value whatsoever. - Martyn Lloyd-Jones.

22 JULY.part4: Because the law worketh wrath: for where no law is, there is no transgression.
22 JULY.part5:
Not only does the law nullify faith and renders the promise of salvation useless [v. 14], but the law also "worketh wrath" [v. 15]. Instead of bringing about salvation, the law condemns and brings judgment upon sinners. Imagine a person who thinks that by keeping the law, he will, upon dying, be in heaven only to find to his horror, that he is in the "furnace of fire: there shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth" [Matthew 13:42]. Not only did his efforts fail to save him, they actually condemned him. The reason? That was the very purpose for which the law was set up.

The law says "Do this, if not, expect judgment." But the law offers nothing for man to fulfil it. And if the law means what it says, it offers no reprieve either. "Keep the law or else ... " If that is the case, is the law a death trap? The answer is a definitive no! Paul states categorically that "the law is holy, and the commandment holy, and just, and good" [Romans 7:12]. The law was set up for a particular purpose. James Montgomery Boice illustrates it this way - "A mirror is not a defective mirror because it cannot clean your face. That is just not its job. The function of a mirror is to show you that your face is dirty so that ... you will get some soap and water and wash it. In the same way, the law is not bad (defective) because it cannot save you ... The law was given to show you that you cannot get to heaven by keeping it, so that ... you will turn to Jesus Christ and be saved by Him."

However, if you insist on keeping the law to save yourself, the very law you trust to save will condemn you because no sinner has ever kept the law perfectly and no one ever will. Condemned by the law or saved by grace - the choice is obvious.
22 JULY.part7: The LORD says, "I have no pleasure in the death of the wicked; but that the wicked turn from his way and live: turn ye, turn ye from your evil ways; for why will ye die, O house of Israel?" [Ezekiel 33:11]

23 JULY.part4: Therefore it is of faith, that it might be by grace; to the end the promise might be sure to all the seed; not to that only which is of the law, but to that also which is of the faith of Abraham; who is the father of us all.
23 JULY.part5:
If salvation does not come by the keeping of the law, how are sinners saved? By grace through faith [Ephesians 2:8]. This was the path of faith taken by Abraham - "He believed in the LORD; and he counted it to him for righteousness" [Genesis 15:6]. Just as works and law are conceptual twins, so are grace and faith. Law shines its spotlight on our actions, behaviour, conduct and deeds. Law lays its demands squarely on us - our works, what we are to do and not to do.

In contrast, grace, which is the unmerited favour of God without any contribution on our part, comes to us by our simple believing - in other words, by faith. If a person works for a living, his wages are earned. The employer is obliged to pay the worker at the end of the day. By doing so, the employer is not being gracious but merely keeping his end of the agreement. Quid pro quo - work gets done; worker gets paid.

However, if the worker falls sick and is unable to work, and the employer continues to pay him; that is grace. The worker did nothing to deserve his wages, and the employer is not obliged to pay him but he does. In the first of His beatitudes, our Lord says, "Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven" [Matthew 5:3]. How can a destitute inherit the kingdom of heaven? Certainly not by his own efforts. Therefore, it has to be given to him by grace, and he accepts it by faith.

Praise the LORD our salvation comes by grace and not anything on our part!
23 JULY.part7: Grace and faith are the conceptual twins of salvation. Grace demands faith. Faith establishes grace.

24 JULY.part4: Therefore it is of faith, that it might be by grace; to the end the promise might be sure to all the seed; not to that only which is of the law, but to that also which is of the faith of Abraham; who is the father of us all.
24 JULY.part5:
This doctrine of grace grates against the sinner's self-reliance and insults his sense of self- worth. So, for the sake of argument, suppose that our salvation is conditional upon our ability to keep the law and to stick to a standard of morality - like being truthful. The question is how truthful must we be in order to be saved. If a man is 99 percent honest, would he earn the right to go to heaven? What about a second man who is just short of 99 percent because he told one more white lie? Where would we draw the line? What is the moral grade that gives one entry into heaven and denies another?

The point is that it is impossible to draw such a line. Any line conceived by man would be arbitrary. That poses a serious problem for one to be saved by good works. How much good works must he do? No one knows because no one knows if he has done enough, which means no one is certain. A man living under such a cloud of uncertainty will either be miserable or misguided. Such a person would either be doomed by his own futility or deceived by his self-righteousness.

Salvation by grace on the other hand is certain because God is faithful. His promises fail not. We can be "confident ... that He which hath begun a good work in you will perform it until the day of Jesus Christ" [Philippians 1:6]. And Christ "is able also to save (us) to the uttermost that come unto God by Him, seeing He ever liveth to make intercession for (us)" [Hebrews 7:25].

God has given us His only begotten Son, and the Son has made the perfect sacrifice so that in Him, we can be confident and assured of our salvation.
24 JULY.part7: All thy sins were laid on Him, Jesus bore them on the tree; God, who knew them, laid them on Him, And believing , thou art free.

25 JULY.part4: Therefore it is of faith, that it might be by grace; to the end the promise might be sure to all the seed; not to that only which is of the law, but to that also which is of the faith of Abraham; who is the father of us all.
25 JULY.part5:
Salvation is not by works, therefore giving hope to all sinners - including you and me - whose lives are wrecked by sin. Salvation is also not by circumcision, which gives hope to all Gentiles. Salvation is not by law because by the law is the knowledge of sin.

Salvation is only "of faith, that it might be by grace". The phrase "faith of Abraham" is also referenced in verses 11 and 12 in association with circumcision, the Jewish covenantal sign. In other words, only Jews were of "the faith of Abraham". However, in verse 16, the promise is to "all the seed; not to that only which is of the law".

We see here an expansion of the scope of those who belong to the "faith of Abraham" from the Jews [v. 11-12] to "all the seed" [v. 16]. In other words, all who believe whether they be Jews or Gentiles are "of the faith of Abraham; who is the father of us all".

Faith opens the door of salvation to all. The promise of salvation is not restricted to the Jews or a few Gentiles. It is open to all who will humble themselves and confess with the mouth the Lord Jesus and believe in their heart that God hath raised Him from the dead (see Romans 10:9). The promise of salvation is open to all. Jew or Gentile, the Gospel is for you. Rich or poor, the Gospel is for you. Learned or illiterate, the Gospel is for you. At the foot of the cross, we are all reduced to the same level - sinners in desperate need of God's saving grace through faith.
25 JULY.part7: If you are excluded from the Gospel, it is only because you prefer your sullied rags of righteousness than the pristine robe of righteousness of our Lord Jesus Christ.

26 JULY.part4: (As it is written, I have made thee a father of many nations,) before him whom he believed, even God, who quickeneth the dead, and calleth those things which be not as though they were.
26 JULY.part5:
The parenthetical statement in verse 17 must be linked to verse 16. "Abraham, who is the father of us all" is also the "father of many nations". From the Old Testament, it seemed there was distinction between the Jews and the rest of the peoples. God had chosen the nation of Israel "to be a special people unto Himself, above all people that are upon the face of the earth" [Deuteronomy 7:6]. The reason for this so-called distinction is that God chose the Israelites to be the ones through whom the Messiah would be born, and the Messiah would come from the line of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob [Genesis 12:1-3]. Paul in addressing the Jews acknowledged that Abraham was known as the "father of circumcision" [Romans 4:12].

But in verse 16, he dispenses with that distinction and says expressly without any discrimination that Abraham "is the father of us all" and "a father of many nations". God does not recognize two separate groups of people upon whom He bestows favour. The Gospel and the promise of salvation by grace is not dependent on ethnicity or the rite of circumcision or the keeping of the law. There is only one group, consisting of all genuine believers, and the promise is through faith alone in Christ Jesus.

Paul - in his epistles - emphasizes this point. He said that Christ "is our peace, who hath made both one, and hath broken down the middle wall of partition between us (Jews and Gentiles)" [Ephesians 2:14]; that "there is neither Jew nor Greek ... for ye are all one in Christ Jesus. And if ye be Christ's, then are ye Abraham's seed, and heirs according to the promise" [Galatians 3:28- 29].
26 JULY.part7: The faith of Abraham is one that rested entirely on God, and so must ours be.

27 JULY.part4: (As it is written, I have made thee a father of many nations,) before him whom he believed, even God, who quickeneth the dead, and calleth those things which be not as though they were.
27 JULY.part5:
In Romans 4:17, Paul describes two attributes of God - He quickens and calls. These are the two acts of God which are the bases for Abraham's faith. They describe the starting points of Abraham's faith. They also explain how we come to faith in Christ.

God "quickeneth the dead" means that God who gives life in the first place also has power to raise the dead [Ephesians 1:19-20]. There are several instances in Abraham's life that display his trust on this matter. The first is God's promise that Abraham would be fruitful and be a father of many nations [Genesis 17:4-6]. God made that promise to Abraham when he was old. But Paul tells us that Abraham "being not weak in faith, he considered not his own body now dead, when he was about an hundred years old, neither yet the deadness of Sarah's womb: He staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief; but was strong in faith, giving glory to God" [Romans 4:19-20]. God quickened Abraham's body so that he fathered Isaac when he was a centenarian.

A second instance was God's testing of Abraham by asking him to offer Isaac as a burnt offering. The account in Genesis 22 does not give any hint of Abraham's reluctance. The Bible tells us that "by faith Abraham, when he was tried, offered up Isaac: and he that had received the promises offered up his only begotten son ... accounting that God was able to raise him up, even from the dead; from whence also he received him in a figure" [Hebrews 11:17-19].

It is only as Abraham had such faith in God's power exemplified in raising the dead that he could have believed the promise he would be the father of many nations.

Do you have the faith of Abraham?
27 JULY.part7: Jesus says, "If ye have faith as a grain of mustard seed ... nothing shall be impossible unto you" [Matthew 17:20].

28 JULY.part4: (As it is written, I have made thee a father of many nations,) before him whom he believed, even God, who quickeneth the dead, and calleth those things which be not as though they were.
28 JULY.part5:
The second of God's attributes that Paul describes in Romans 4:17 is that He "calleth those things which be not as though they were." In Greek, the phrase literally means God "calling the things not being as being". Young's Literal Translation renders it this way - God "is calling the things that be not as being". Another translation has it as God calling "into existence the things that do not exist". The Chinese translation [Shi Wu  Bian Wei You ] means "cause to change from nothing to something".

There are several interpretations to this phrase. Some have taken this phrase to refer to God's creatio ex nihilo - God creating out of nothing. However, Paul does not say that God "calleth into being things that are not" but that God "calleth the things that are not as being". There are others who use this phrase to say that God has control over things actual (things which are) and possible (things which are not); however, there is a huge interpretative gap to cross from "things which be not" into "things possible".

A more accurate reading of this phrase is that Abraham believed the promises that God made to him were as good as fulfilled although they had not yet come to pass. Paul writing to the Corinthians on God's calling sinners to salvation uses similar phraseology - "For ye see your calling, brethren, how that not many wise men after the flesh, not many mighty, not many noble, are called ... and things which are not, to bring to nought things that are" [1 Corinthians 1:26-28]. By His sovereign will, God calls sinners who are not saints as though they are, on account of what Christ's redemptive work has accomplished.

God's promise was for Abraham as good as fulfilment. It is on this truth that Abraham's faith rested.
28 JULY.part7: Faith is the belief that God will do what He has promised in spite of your present circumstances.

29 JULY.part4: Who against hope believed in hope, that he might become the father of many nations, according to that which was spoken, So shall thy seed be.
29 JULY.part5:
"I hope to lose weight." "I hope it will not rain tomorrow." These statements expressing hope are mere wishes which have no absolute certainty of fulfilment. This is not what the Bible means by hope. The biblical definition of hope is "confident expectation". The writer of Hebrews says that "faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen" [Hebrews 11:1], meaning that it is the assurance of things that are yet unknown. Hope is a key component of the believer's life. Without hope, life loses its meaning. The Bible exhorts us: "Let not thine heart envy sinners: but be thou in the fear of the LORD all the day long. For surely there is an end; And thine expectation (or hope) shall not be cut off " [Proverbs 23:17-18].

In Romans 4:18, the object of Abraham's hope was the fulfilment of God's promise that he would have a son, and from which all the promises of God flow - "I will make thee exceeding fruitful, and I will make nations of thee ... I will establish my covenant between me and thee and thy seed after thee ... for an everlasting covenant ... I will give unto thee, and to thy seed after thee ... and I will be their God" [Genesis 17:6-8].

For years, the promises did not come to pass, but Abraham's faith never waned, and his hope never diminished. And in God's appointed time, all these promises were fulfilled to the jot and tittle.

The Christian's hope is found in Christ. He alone is our hope [1 Timothy 1:1], and by His resurrection, we have a "lively hope" [1 Peter 1:3]. So we persevere and press on because of the certain expectation of Christ's promises.
29 JULY.part7: When I fear my faith will fail, Christ will hold me fast.

30 JULY.part4: Who against hope believed in hope, that he might become the father of many nations, according to that which was spoken, So shall thy seed be.
30 JULY.part5:
There is a hiking trail in Vancouver called the Grouse Grind. It is a three-kilometre trail up the face of Grouse Mountain. Our journey so far through Paul's epistle to the Romans has been somewhat like a spiritual Grouse Grind. From its opening words, Paul has been leading us - step by step - up the mountain of truth. At times, the climb has been tough and challenging because of the steep doctrinal incline. Now, we are nearing the top, and we begin to see a glimpse of what lies ahead.

Abraham's pilgrimage of faith has not been an easy one. In verse 18, Paul says that Abraham "against hope believed in hope". The phrases "against hope" and "in hope" are diametrically opposed. "Against hope" describes all the circumstances that - from a human perspective - have no possibility of fulfilment. "Against hope" was what Abraham knew from human experience, that it was impossible for a man as old as he was to father a son, much less be a father of many nations [v. 17-18].

When Paul says Abraham "believed in hope", it does not mean that Abraham had faith in his own hope. Rather, when Abraham "believed in hope", he is exercising faith in what God has promised. "In hope" is the working out of faith in God even when the circumstances are impossible. "In hope" is what Abraham believed, and he is "fully persuaded that, what (God) had promised, He was able also to perform" [v. 21].

Faith and hope are complementary and inextricably linked. Faith is unreserved trust in God and His promises, and hope is the confident certainty of absolute fulfilment of God's promises.
30 JULY.part7: The certainty of our hope is dependent upon our faith in God and His promises.

31 JULY.part4: Who against hope believed in hope, that he might become the father of many nations, according to that which was spoken, So shall thy seed be.
31 JULY.part5:
In Romans 4:18, Paul lists two promises that God made to Abraham; that he would be "the father of many nations" [Genesis 17:4], and that as he was, "so shall thy seed be" [Genesis 15:5]. Both promises fell within the scope of Abraham's faith. Both promises were "according to that which was spoken" [v. 18].

Commenting on this verse, Martyn Lloyd-Jones said that Abraham's faith was based on "the bare Word of God and on nothing else whatsoever". When God first gave that promise to Abraham, he was seventy-five years old [Genesis 12]; then the situation might not seem so hopeless. At eighty- five years old [Genesis 15], there might have been some tension of trust in Abraham. It would not be accurate to say that Abraham did not experience a struggle in his faith. He did! [Genesis 17:17-18].

But that tension of trust was immediately assuaged when God told Abraham, "Sarah thy wife shall bear thee a son indeed; and thou shalt call his name Isaac: and I will establish my covenant with him for an everlasting covenant, and with his seed after him" [Genesis 17:19]. It was on that spoken word, that Abraham believed in the LORD. It is in this sense that Abraham's faith did not waver and was even strengthened.

Can we have faith like Abraham's? The answer is yes! That which saves us is the bare Word of God, and that which sustains and strengthens us in the faith is also the bare Word of God. Apart from the Word of God, we know nothing about our future. So, if we would know anything of the hope we have in Christ, it has to be the bare Word of God.
31 JULY.part7: Christ says, "For verily I say unto you, till heaven and earth pass, one jot or one tittle shall in no wise pass from the law, till all be fulfilled" [Matthew 5:18].

1 AUGUST.part4: And being not weak in faith, he considered not his own body now dead, when he was about an hundred years old, neither yet the deadness of Sara's womb.
1 AUGUST.part5:
God first called Abraham in Ur of the Chaldees [Acts 7:2-3] and then again at Haran. He promised to give Abraham a land, make him a great nation and a great name, and he and his descendants would be a blessing to the nations of the world [Genesis 12:1-3]. By faith in God, Abraham obeyed, took his family, departed from Haran and journeyed on.

"By faith Abraham, when he was called to go out into a place which he should after receive for an inheritance, obeyed; and he went out, not knowing whither he went. By faith he sojourned in the land of promise, as in a strange country, dwelling in tabernacles with Isaac and Jacob, the heirs with him of the same promise: For he looked for a city which hath foundations, whose builder and maker is God." [Hebrews 11:8-10]

When God called Abraham, He divinely prompted faith in Abraham's heart. Abraham believed the One, who had called, to be the true and living God whom he could trust wholeheartedly - God Omnipotent, Omniscient, Omnipresent, Creator of heaven and earth, Holy and Righteous, Immutable and Faithful - Who will not lie nor break His promises. Abraham's faith in God was strong and unwavering.

By faith, "Abraham believed God and it was counted unto him for righteousness" [Romans 4:3]. Abraham was justified and saved. Dear reader, for your salvation, by faith believe in God's promise - "Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and thou shalt be saved, and thy house." [Acts 16:31]. May the Lord grant us an unwavering faith to trust and obey Him always to the glory of His name.
1 AUGUST.part7: For all the promises of God in Him are yea, and in Him Amen, unto the glory of God by us. - 2 Corinthians 1:20

2 AUGUST.part4: And being not weak in faith, he considered not his own body now dead, when he was about an hundred years old, neither yet the deadness of Sara's womb.
2 AUGUST.part5:
Through his sojourn and even after settling down in Canaan, Abraham and Sarah remained childless even though God had repeatedly assured Abraham of His promise: "And he brought him forth abroad, and said, Look now toward heaven, and tell the stars, if thou be able to number them: and he said unto him, So shall thy seed be. And he believed in the LORD; and he counted it to him for righteousness." [Genesis 15:5-6; 17:21; 18:11-18].

Abraham had not witnessed any miracle by God nor was there any physical evidence that a man or woman their age could still bear children for "his own body now dead ... neither yet the deadness of Sarah's womb". Yet Abraham exercised living faith in God - trusted Him for forty years now - and believed in this "God, who quickeneth the dead, and calleth those things which be not as though they were" [v. 17]. Abraham was confident God would fulfil His promise and perform it to the uttermost. When Abraham was a hundred years old, God miraculously quickened Abraham's "dead body" and Sarah's "dead womb". Sarah conceived and bore him the son of promise, Isaac [Genesis 21:1-3].

We were at one time spiritually dead in sin and trespasses. By God's grace and mercy, we were quickened unto life [Ephesians 2:1], saved by grace through faith [Ephesians 2:8] in our Lord Jesus who died for our sins and resurrected to redeem us unto everlasting life. In humble gratitude to our Saviour, we exercise our living faith by conforming to Him and living for Him even though the body dies. True faith never dies but is living and lives on.
2 AUGUST.part7: Even so faith, if it hath not works, is dead, being alone. - James 2:17

3 AUGUST.part4: He staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief; but was strong in faith, giving glory to God.
3 AUGUST.part5:
By faith Abraham left Haran and continued his journey to the land of promise. God, in His initial call to Abraham, had promised He would make from Abraham a great nation and his descendants would be as many as the stars in heaven, but through the years of sojourning and even on arrival in Canaan, God's promises still had not materialized. Yet Abraham did not stagger in unbelief or doubt. Abraham's spiritual eyes were fixed on God and not on his circumstances. God was the object and the source of his faith.

Noah, when called upon by God to build an ark [Genesis 6:14], obeyed because God had told Noah that He would "bring a flood of waters upon the earth" [Genesis 6:17]. Noah believed God, his faith did not waver. He persevered in building the Ark, and his family was saved.

The ten spies, on account of their doubt, fears and unbelief perished in the wilderness. Joshua and Caleb exercised believing faith, and God allowed them into the Promised Land.

Peter was able to walk on water as long as he looked at the Lord Jesus. But when he turned and noticed the boisterous waves, he began to sink. Then Jesus held him and rebuked him for his doubt and little faith [Matthew 14:24-31]. How often the surging waves of doubt can weaken one's faith rendering one ineffective for God.

May the Lord deliver us from the sin of unbelief and fear so that our faith will not stagger. May He find us faithful until we reach our Promised Land.
3 AUGUST.part7: But without faith it is impossible to please Him: for he that cometh to God must believe that He is, and that He is a rewarder of them that diligently seek Him. - Hebrews 11:6

4 AUGUST.part4: He staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief; but was strong in faith, giving glory to God.
4 AUGUST.part5:
After Abraham arrived in Canaan, still childless and landless, his faith was further tested. He encountered famine [Genesis 12:10], a potentially hostile Pharoah [Genesis 12:14-20], conflict with his nephew Lot [Genesis13:5-9] and experienced fear [Genesis 15:1]. While God had prompted faith in Abraham's heart, He tested and strengthened it by not immediately fulfilling His promises. But through the years of waiting, God graciously reiterated His promises to Abraham [Genesis 15:4- 5; 17:21; 18:1-18].

By God's mercy and grace, He gave us the faith to believe in Him and His Son, our Lord and Saviour [Ephesians 1:4-5; 2:8]. He strengthens our faith by assuring us of our salvation in Christ's finished work at Calvary [Hebrews 10:10-12, 14]; that He will perfect the good work He has begun in us [Philippians 1:6]; and that He will never leave us nor forsake us [Deuteronomy 31:6, 8]. Our faith will be tried betimes [1 Peter 1:7] but nothing can separate us from God's love [Romans 8:35, 38-39]. Christ has given us His rest ([Matthew 11:28-30], peace [John 14:27], the Holy Spirit [John 14:16-17] and He is coming again for us [John 14:1-6].

So, strengthen your faith in God, draw nigh to Him [James 4:8] daily in worship and prayer [1 Thessalonians 5:16-18], in studying and meditating upon His Word [2 Timothy 2:15] and growing in grace and knowledge of the Lord [2 Peter 3:18]. Let us be resolved to lead sanctified lives with eternity's values in view [Colossians 3:1-17]. Our salvation is purchased with such a great price as the precious blood of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, let us surrender our lives to serve and honour Him [Romans 12:1-2].
4 AUGUST.part7: Looking unto Jesus the author and finisher of our faith; who for the joy that was set before Him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God. - Hebrews 12:2

5 AUGUST.part4: And being fully persuaded that, what he had promised, he was able also to perform.
5 AUGUST.part5:
The promises of God are an announcement by God about what He is going to do. It shows God's voluntary undertaking of an action. Here, God promised patriarch Abraham a son to be born by Sarah. God promised He would make Abraham a father of many nations [Genesis 17:4].

Promises and their fulfilments are dependent on the one who makes the promise. The will and desire of the "promiser" are revealed and further confirmed by the fulfilment of the promise and his track record. Promises also reflect the relationship between the parties involved. An understanding of the character, ability and trustworthiness of the promiser is key to whether he is to be believed and can be trusted.

Thus, the promises of God are secured by His revealed character. He is gracious and the promises made are gracious toward His creatures. God's promises are true for He does not lie. We know His promises will come to pass as He is the Sovereign Almighty God, who has been faithful and has kept every single one of His promises to us. God sending His Son Jesus Christ to save us from our sins is the fulfilment of His greatest promise to us, proving He is who He says He is and will do exactly as He says.

"God is not a man that He should lie; neither the son of man that He should repent: hath He said, and shall He not do it? or hath He spoken and shall He not make it good?" [Numbers 23:19]. "For all the promises of God in Him are yea and in Him Amen, unto the glory of God by us" [2 Corinthians 1:20].
5 AUGUST.part7: In hope of eternal life, which God, that cannot lie, promised before the world began. -Titus 1:2

6 AUGUST.part4: And being fully persuaded that, what he had promised, he was able also to perform.
6 AUGUST.part5:
Abraham knew God and His character in an intimate way, leading him to be fully persuaded of His trustworthiness. To be fully persuaded is a description of true faith. Abraham came to the point of being fully assured, totally submitting and placing faith in God. He surrendered to God wholeheartedly. Abraham was fully convinced and assured of the eventual outcome.

Abraham exhibited faith by his action in obeying God when He called him out of Ur of the Chaldees [Genesis 12:1-4]. The Word of God records for us how Abraham struggled with his faith at times, even initially doubting the promise he would have a child by Sarah [Genesis 16:2; 17:17]. Yet in time, he reached the point when he was fully assured that God would do as He promised.

That is precisely the journey of faith for God's children. The child of God begins with a little faith as a grain of mustard seed which grows over time till it becomes a faith that can move mountains. As faith in God grows by our continually turning to Him, trusting Him and His Word in the changing scenes of life, we will grow to know and trust Him deeper.

Thus assurance (being fully persuaded) grows out of such faith. The child of God's initial faith is given by God. Thus, even when struggling with little faith, he is in fact humbly crying out for more faith: "Lord I believe: help Thou mine unbelief " [Mark 9:24].
6 AUGUST.part7: Know therefore that the LORD thy God, He is God, the faithful God, which keepeth covenant and mercy with them that love Him and keep His commandments to a thousand generations. - Deuteronomy 7:9

7 AUGUST.part4: And being fully persuaded that, what he had promised, he was able also to perform.
7 AUGUST.part5:
Abraham knew God's promises. His faith in God grew over time even as he went through trials and found Him faithful and further surrendered to Him. He thus gained full assurance in God Himself. All this because God had revealed Himself, His character, and shown Himself faithful. All this was dependent on God being able to perform as He said He would. An impotent God would not be able to fulfil His promises. God promised Abraham and Sarah, who were of advanced age and beyond child-bearing years, they would have a child. Humanly speaking, this was an impossibility.

"With men this is impossible; but with God all things are possible" [Matthew 19:26b]. God has revealed Himself to be the Almighty and Sovereign God. He is able to do what man cannot. He has already done what mankind cannot understand fully.

"In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth" [Genesis 1:1]. "Through faith we understand that the worlds were framed by the word of God, so that things which are seen were not made of things which do appear" [Hebrews 11:3].

As God was able to create the universe and physical life from nothing, He can also enable an aged woman to conceive if He wills it. God was able to bring forth His Son from a virgin [Isaiah 7:14] and by the Lord Jesus' sinless life, death and resurrection, give spiritual life to those who are spiritually dead [Ephesians 2:1]! Indeed, only God is able to save mankind through Jesus Christ, His only begotten Son.
7 AUGUST.part7: But our God is in the heavens: He hath done whatsoever He hath pleased. - Psalm 115:3

8 AUGUST.part4: And therefore it was imputed to him for righteousness.
8 AUGUST.part5:
What man is unable to do, God is able to. By man's own ability and on his own account, he is helpless to attain to the perfect righteousness God requires for entry into His sinless heavenly abode. If we depend on ourselves, then we are all completely hopeless and doomed.

But God in His infinite love and wisdom provided the means. He would put on our account the very righteousness He requires. This unilateral provision for man's deliverance He made from the time of man's fall until this present age comes to a close and the sinful world order is destroyed and restored to its original state of perfection, was exemplified by the patriarch Abraham of whom it is said: "And he believed in the LORD; and he counted it to him for righteousness" [Genesis 15:6].

This righteousness was not Abraham's on account of his works but imputed to him on account of his faith in believing and obeying the Lord.

Under the Old Covenant, the perfect sacrifice for sin was foreshadowed and typified in the sacrifices prescribed by the Law. In the covenant of the New Testament, this perfect and ultimate sacrifice was made manifest and clear to all in the life, death and resurrection of the incarnate Second person of the Godhead - Jesus Christ, the Son of God. His sinless righteousness is imputed to all who believe and accept Him by faith as their Lord and Saviour. Not by works lest any man should boast. This is the only acceptable means by which entrance into God's heavenly home is granted.
8 AUGUST.part7: No other way! - "Jesus saith unto him, I am the Way, the Truth, and the Life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by Me" [John 14:6].

9 AUGUST.part4: But for us also, to whom it shall be imputed, if we believe on him that raised up Jesus our Lord from the dead;
9 AUGUST.part5:
God chose and called Abraham from the myriads of people in history. His family background was idol-worshipping. There was nothing special in him that merited his choice. But Abraham exercised faith to believe God's promises and obey God's directions and that counted as sufficient righteousness for his salvation.

For us too, who have nothing to boast, God is calling. For us too will only such simple believing faith open the gates for God's grace to flow and cover us with the righteousness of the Risen Christ, but only if we believe and obey what God has revealed to us in His Son the living Word and His written Word. For us too will the righteousness of the Son of God alone be necessary and sufficient for admittance into the presence of the most holy God.

More privileged than Abraham, we now possess the complete canon of Scripture and have a full picture. The Lord Jesus came into our world to save us. God's Son was the perfect atoning sacrifice for our sins and His righteousness is imputed to all who believe so that we are made acceptable to God. This work of Christ was finished on the cross. No more types and shadows of the promised Deliverer, but "We see Jesus, who was made a little lower than the angels for the suffering of death, crowned with glory and honour; that he by the grace of God should taste death for every man." [Hebrews 2:9]. So, heed God's Word and live!

Salvation is by faith though grace, then, now and forevermore [Ephesians 2:8].
9 AUGUST.part7: Even as Abraham believed God, and it was accounted to him for righteousness. Know ye therefore that they which are of faith, the same are the children of Abraham. - Galatians 3:6-7

10 AUGUST.part4: But for us also, to whom it shall be imputed, if we believe on him that raised up Jesus our Lord from the dead;
10 AUGUST.part5:
To the Philippian jailer who asked what he needed to do for salvation, the apostle replied, "Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and thou shalt be saved, and thy house" [Acts 16:31]. To the Roman Christians, Paul again said, "That if thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved." [Romans 10:9]

In His epic encounter with Nicodemus, the Lord Jesus said, "For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in Him should not perish, but have everlasting life" [John 3:16]. And then as if to make sure there would be no doubt about what He said, the Lord reiterated, "He that believeth on him is not condemned: but he that believeth not is condemned already, because he hath not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God" [John 3:18].

Man can never be saved by his sin-tainted works and best-intended efforts. Because of our sin-nature, our "righteousnesses are as filthy rags" [Isaiah 64:6]. Only the untainted righteousness of the sinless paschal Lamb of God put on our account will meet God's perfect standard and make us acceptable to Him who can tolerate no sin. Salvation is of the Lord, but we must believe this. God the Father provided the only Way in God the Son, our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, so we can be saved.
10 AUGUST.part7: I will greatly rejoice in the LORD, my soul shall be joyful in my God; for He hath clothed me with the garments of salvation, He hath covered me with the robe of righteousness, as a bridegroom decketh himself with ornaments, and as a bride adorneth herself with her jewels. - Isaiah 61:10

11 AUGUST.part4: Who was delivered for our offences, and was raised again for our justification.
11 AUGUST.part5:
The uniqueness of the Christian faith lies in the fact that God saves the unworthy and the undeserving by providing the means for meeting the standard He has set for these to be accepted by Him. His standard of holiness and purity befitting the holy and righteous God is infinitely high. Left to our own devices, the best of man's efforts, our good works, our meritorious achievements all amount to nothing and fall hopelessly short. The mere scent of sin will sully the purity of God's heavenly kingdom.

So, the loving and wise God sent His only begotten Son - sinless and divine, equal to Himself in substance, power and glory - to do the impossible for us.
