Jesus the Messiah took on human form to be the sinless sacrifice and acceptable atonement for all humanity's sin. Christ alone could satisfy God's holy standards. Christ alone could do what generations of priests and countless animal sacrifices could not. Divinity alone could accomplish what mortal flesh could never do. The Saviour would die so that sin's penalty was paid in full, God's justice fully satisfied and His divine love manifested all in one perfect sacrifice.

The Son of God was delivered for our offences, despised and rejected by men, wounded and bruised for our transgressions. The chastisement which procures our peace with God was put on Him. The Father laid the iniquity of mankind upon His Son. He went to the cross and suffered the death of a common criminal so that sinful man can live again. Hallelujah, what a Saviour, what a gift!
11 AUGUST.part7: God's perfect love and absolute justice are fulfilled in the Lord Jesus Christ. "For if by one man's (Adam's) offence death reigned by one; much more they which receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness shall reign in life by one, Jesus Christ" [Romans 5:17].

12 AUGUST.part4: Who was delivered for our offences, and was raised again for our justification.
12 AUGUST.part5:
If Jesus Christ the Son of God had died and remained in the grave, He would have been like any other man, another great martyr in history giving his life for a cause. His death would be considered a noble sacrifice but that would be the sum of it and soon forgotten. Those who believed and placed their trust in Him, who followed and suffered for His sake would have believed and trusted a lie. There would be no consequences for the wicked and no vindication for the righteous. Paul told the Corinthians, "If Christ be not raised, your faith is in vain; ye are yet in your sins ... If in this life only we have hope in Christ, we are of all men most miserable" [1 Corinthians 15:17, 19]. How true!

But our Lord Jesus did not remain in the tomb. Death could not retain Him just as darkness cannot resist light, for this our Christ is the light of the world and in Him is the light of life. Jesus said, "Because I live, ye shall live also" [John 14:19]. His was no empty boast. The Saviour of the world who died for our sins rose again from the grave as He said He would, so death was vanquished and everlasting life a reality.

The Lord Jesus said to Martha, "I am the Resurrection, and the Life: he that believeth in Me, though he were dead, yet shall he live: And whosoever liveth and believeth in Me shall never die. Believest thou this?" [John 11:25-26]

What is your answer?
12 AUGUST.part7: Resurrection of the dead to eternal life - the linchpin of the Gospel. Read 1 Corinthians 15.

13 AUGUST.part4: Therefore being justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ:
13 AUGUST.part5:
Romans 5:1 is a powerful verse. It states unequivocally that we sinners can only be made right with God through faith in the Lord Jesus Christ who died for us on the cross. As believers and disciples of Christ, we are then able to enjoy this wonderful relationship with God. God's grace works to restore us and help us recognise the need to trust and obey the Lord.

Through Christ, we are justified. We can neither justify ourselves by good works nor rely on our own will to be obedient to the law. We were all alienated from God by our sin nature, unable to bridge the chasm between God and man. Proverbs 28:13 tells us that it is human nature for us to cover our sins but only those who confess and seek forgiveness will find mercy. Blessed is he whose transgression is forgiven [Psalm 32:1].

The only way to reconcile with God is through believing that Jesus Christ is the Saviour. Justification is by faith alone, and not of works, lest any man should boast [Ephesians 2:8-9]. It is the gift of God. Only through Christ can we taste the sweetness of peace with God. We can rest in Him with the assurance of eternal salvation. It is an amazing experience to have this peace.

We will only enjoy true peace when we are made right with God and stand justified before Him. Isaiah 32:17 reminds us that "the work of righteousness shall be peace; and the effect of righteousness quietness and assurance for ever."
13 AUGUST.part7: For he is our peace, who hath made both one, and hath broken down the middle wall of partition between us. - Ephesians 2:14

14 AUGUST.part2: Peace of God and Peace with God
14 AUGUST.part4: Therefore being justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ:
14 AUGUST.part5:
Romans 5:1 speaks of "peace with God" rather than the "peace of God". But it is true that when we believe in the Lord, we will enjoy the peace of God that transcends all human understanding. In times of anxiety and stress, believers of Christ are able to turn our worries into prayers and enjoy the peace of God which Philippians 4:6-7 talks about.

However, to enjoy God's peace in our hearts, we need first to establish our peace with Him through faith in our Lord Jesus Christ. Apostle Paul in Romans 1 speaks of the sinfulness of mankind. Throughout history even up to the present, sin has driven man to pursue the passions of the world and neglect God's truth and way. We grieve the Holy Spirit when we put ourselves above God in our daily thoughts and actions. Our God is just and He cannot let sin go unpunished. Thankfully, in His mercy and grace, He satisfied His wrath against men in Jesus Christ. The Lord Jesus shed His blood for us and we receive the benefits of His atonement by believing in Him, which leads to the establishing of peace with God.

Peace has been provided by God sending His only Son to wash away our sins. Peace is received by us when our sins are forgiven through our repentance and faith in Christ. This peace gives us strength and courage to weather the trials of life. Nothing can take away our eternal security and the peace God has made with us because now we can boldly (confidently) seek His help in time of need [Hebrews 4:16].
14 AUGUST.part7: O Lord my God, thank You for giving me the assurance that I have eternal peace with You. Strengthen my faith and let me be Your witness to others. Help me to share this wonderful Gospel with unsaved souls. Amen.

15 AUGUST.part4: By whom also we have access by faith into this grace wherein we stand, and rejoice in hope of the glory of God.
15 AUGUST.part5:
The Greek word translated "access" has the meaning of "introduction" or "the right and freedom to enter". To the Jews, it was unthinkable that man could have direct access to God. Our sins made us offensive to the holy God so we could never approach Him. In the Temple, a heavy curtain served as a barrier to entry into the Holy of Holies where God's divine presence was manifested. None could enter in except the High Priest who went in only once a year to make atonement for the sins of the nation and for himself. Even then, he could not enter unworthily lest he lose his life.

The death of our Lord Jesus Christ on Calvary's cross put an end to that. Although He was righteous and sinless, He bore all our sins upon Himself and faced the wrath of the Father by enduring the punishment we should have had. God the Father accepted the atoning sacrifice of His Son as evidenced by the tearing of the veil separating the Holy of Holies from the rest of the Temple [Matthew 27:51], a sign we can now approach God directly on the merit of our Saviour's work on the cross. Priests are no longer needed to be man's mediators before God.

There are no other means for us to have peace with God and gain access to Him, except by believing and accepting that the Lord Jesus Christ saved us from our sins. Have you placed your faith in the Saviour to do that?
15 AUGUST.part7: For through Him we both have access by one Spirit unto the Father. - Ephesians 2:18

16 AUGUST.part4: By whom also we have access by faith into this grace wherein we stand, and rejoice in hope of the glory of God.
16 AUGUST.part5:
The death of our Lord Jesus Christ on the cross for our sins results in His righteousness being imputed to us who believe. Now we stand before God, not as sinners and children of wrath but as His own, redeemed by the blood of the Lamb. Our adoption as sons and daughters of our heavenly Father grants us "access with confidence" to Him [Ephesians 3:12]. We have confidence God will hear our prayers and answer them according to His wise and perfect will. There is no fear God will ignore or refuse to answer because we have been justified by faith in Jesus to save us. This assurance should move us to come boldly and freely before God's throne of grace with all our petitions and intercessions.

Our justification also affords us confidence before God because our position as His child is firm and immovable. We are saved by God's grace and kept saved by it. Our almighty and loving God is willing and able to keep us in His grace. Our Father who began a good work in us will perform it until we get to heaven [Philippians 1:6]. Christ's atoning death covers all our sins before our conversion and every iniquity thereafter. Our salvation is preserved and maintained not by our own efforts, thus there is no fear we can lose it through ignorance or neglect.

Even as we seek our gracious Father each day, let us present our petitions to Him in the knowledge that He loves to commune with us and desires to bless us richly with His abundant mercies.
16 AUGUST.part7: Having therefore, brethren, boldness to enter into the holiest by the blood of Jesus, let us draw near with a true heart in full assurance of faith. - Hebrews 10:19, 22a

17 AUGUST.part2: Glory of the Father and the Son
17 AUGUST.part4: By whom also we have access by faith into this grace wherein we stand, and rejoice in hope of the glory of God.
17 AUGUST.part5:
The glory of God is rich in meaning and impossible to explain in a simple sentence because it encompasses several spiritual concepts.

Firstly, glory is given to God who is the Almighty, so magnificent and excellent that He deserves our highest esteem and adoration. When we glorify and worship God, we are assigning to Him His true worth of being greatest of all. Our God is most worthy to be praised and most deserving of honour and glory because of who He is in His attributes. Thus the angels who worshipped God when they appeared to the shepherds at the birth of our Lord Jesus proclaimed, "Glory to God in the highest" [Luke 2:14].

Secondly, the shekinah glory describes the visible manifestation of God's glory. It shines so brilliantly it cannot be approached. This glory reflected off Moses' face after he spent forty days and nights on Mount Sinai with God causing the Israelites to fear looking at him [Exodus 34:29-35]. The same glory descended onto the tabernacle [Exodus 40:34-38] and the Temple [1 Kings 8:10-11] so that Moses and the priests could not enter in to minister.

At the mount of Transfiguration, the disciples, Peter, James and John were given a glimpse of the glory that Jesus, the Son of God, shared with the Father [Matthew 17:1-5]. When Christ came to earth, His glory was hidden from man. His transfiguration revealed momentarily His glory to the disciples so they could bear witness of it. It was also a preview of His future glorification as King of kings. May we His disciples also acknowledge God's greatness and seek to glorify His name by our lives.
17 AUGUST.part7: Glory to God and praise and love, be ever, ever given, By saints below and saints above, the church in earth and heaven. - Charles Wesley

18 AUGUST.part4: By whom also we have access by faith into this grace wherein we stand, and rejoice in hope of the glory of God.
18 AUGUST.part5:
Our justification grants us peace with God [v. 1] and access to Him. It enables us to rejoice in the hope of His glory. Paul was telling all Christians that we can be so joyful as to boast in the certainty we will possess the glory of God one day.

This glory is too wonderful and marvellous to comprehend. We will behold God's glory in heaven because we will live eternally with Him, clothed in the righteousness of our Saviour. God's Word promises us that when we die, we will be raised again. Our vile and perishable bodies will be "fashioned like unto his glorious body" [Philippians 3:21]. It will be immortal [1 Corinthians 15:53-54] and we will see Christ as He is [1 John 3:2].

Job, in the midst of suffering, demonstrated a clear understanding of the resurrection when he said, "though after my skin worms destroy this body, yet in my flesh I shall see God" [Job 19:26]. He had faith God would raise him, give him a glorified body and he would see Jesus in heaven. At the Transfiguration, Moses and Elijah, who had died centuries earlier, appeared with the Lord Jesus in glorified bodies, signifying that believers who have died will enjoy eternal life in God's glory because our hope is in the Christ.

What an incredible hope God has promised us. May we lay aside every doubt and fear, and live joyfully in anticipation of that blessed day when we will appear before our Lord in glory.
18 AUGUST.part7: Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, which according to His abundant mercy hath begotten us again unto a lively hope by the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead, to an inheritance incorruptible, and undefiled, and that fadeth not away, reserved in heaven for you. - 1 Peter 1:3-4

19 AUGUST.part4: And not only so, but we glory in tribulations also: knowing that tribulation worketh patience;
19 AUGUST.part5:
Not only do we rejoice in the hope of the glory of God, but we glory in our present sufferings and afflictions. Take note it is one thing to submit to or endure tribulations without complaint, but it is quite another to find grounds for glorying in the midst of them. As old soldiers glory in their battle scars of honour, so do believers glory in their present sufferings and afflictions.

Paul experienced many sufferings for the sake of the Gospel. He was whipped, beaten with rods, stoned, and shipwrecked [2 Corinthians 11:24- 25]. Peter and the apostles in Acts 5:27 were apprehended for preaching yet they were found "rejoicing that they were counted worthy to suffer shame for his name" [Acts 5:41]. Satan detests and despises the Gospel work being done. And he will throw everything in his arsenal to discourage the Christian. But we know that not even tribulation can separate us from the love of Christ [Romans 8:35].

The beauty of tribulation is in the end product that comes forth. The purpose of tribulation is not to produce a depressed and downcast Christian but to produce patience, experience, and hope. This is the true test of character. Tribulation tests and examines the Christian's heart, whether he/she is truly saved. And whenever our faith is successfully tested, it will be "found unto (the) praise and honour and glory at the appearing of Jesus Christ" [1 Peter 1:7].
19 AUGUST.part7: Dear God, teach me to rejoice in the midst of trials, and help me to count it worthy to suffer for your name's sake. Amen.

20 AUGUST.part4: And not only so, but we glory in tribulations also: knowing that tribulation worketh patience;
20 AUGUST.part5:
Paul lists three purposes of tribulation, the first being patience. James in his letter reinforces this idea by stating that "the trying of your faith worketh patience" [James 1:3]. Although we desire tribulations to be resolved quickly, it is tribulations that cultivate patience within the believer. When Job lost his wealth, family and livelihood, his wife said to him, "curse God, and die" [Job 2:9]. Job instead, wept, prayed, and patiently endured until he was restored by God.

David is another example. Although Samuel anointed David to be Israel's second king, David waited for God to remove Saul. Saul tried repeatedly to kill David, yet David remained patient until the day he was crowned king. Believers likewise can patiently endure because tribulations have a finite time. Peter describes tribulations and temptations as lasting only for a season implying the temporal nature of tribulations [1 Peter 1:6].

It is in the midst of tribulations that enduring faith in God's Word is tested - whether we stand on His precious promises or become impatient and turn to the world for solutions. The key is the foundation we are standing on. Have you strengthened your faith in God so that you can patiently endure through your tribulation? God's precious promises are like unused gift card credits which we have misplaced. There is much value in God's Word yet we fail to utilize it. Build up your defenses in times of peace so that you can patiently endure when Satan hurls trials and testings your way.
20 AUGUST.part7: Dear Father, teach me to trust in your precious promises so that I can patiently endure the trials of life. Amen.

21 AUGUST.part4: And patience, experience; and experience, hope:
21 AUGUST.part5:
The tribulation which has wrought in us the habit of reliance on God, the patient persistence of endurance, develops in us the virtue of experience. Our modern definition of "experience" refers to the actual living through an event; however, "experience" means "approvedness" or "proof ". Job's tribulation wrought patience, and that patience produced proof that he still "hold(s) fast his integrity" [Job 2:3]. Fake gold will darken under a flame while true gold will glow brighter. Tribulation holds the believer to a flame and proves his character.

Tribulations endured patiently show the believer what he or she is really made of. It validates the believer's faith and trust in God. When we endure, we demonstrate not only to ourselves but also to the world who and what we really are. In Daniel 3 when Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego refused to worship Nebuchadnezzar's golden image, they were thrown into a fiery furnace. Their preservation from death proved they "trusted in Him", referring to God [Daniel 3:28].

Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego's faith also demonstrated the power of the Almighty God. At times our patient endurance and experience speak louder than words. In 1 Peter 3:1, believing wives are to obey God's commandment of submission to the unbelieving husbands so that they would "be won by the (conduct) of the wives".
21 AUGUST.part7: Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven. - Matthew 5:16

22 AUGUST.part4: And hope maketh not ashamed; because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is given unto us.
22 AUGUST.part5:
Patient endurance produces a tested character, and the latter possesses confident hope. Tribulations, rather than threatening or weakening our hope, as might be expected, will instead increase our certainty in that hope. One of the great obstacles to a strong hope in the glory of God is the fear that we are hypocrites. But when our faith has been put to the test and we have patiently endured tribulations, we have hope because it proves that we are genuine and real Christians.

Worldly hope contains several degrees of uncertainty and is deceiving at times. We hope something will happen, and when they don't turn out as we hope for, we are embarrassed and almost always painfully disappointed. But the hope of God's glory does not put us to shame nor will it disappoint us. This hope is "both sure and steadfast" and is based on the certainty of divine love [Hebrews 6:19].

When we patiently endure through tribulations we are assured that our faith is not hypocritical. Will we endure through tribulation in faith and hope and in the end be disappointed? Paul reassures us that we can have an unashamed hope because the Holy Spirit has come into our lives and has begun to flood our hearts with an immediate sense of God's reality and love.
22 AUGUST.part7: ... Behold, I lay in Sion a chief corner stone, elect, precious: and he that believeth on Him shall not be confounded. - 1 Peter 2:6

23 AUGUST.part2: Love of God Shed in our Hearts
23 AUGUST.part4: And hope maketh not ashamed; because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is given unto us.
23 AUGUST.part5:
Paul reminds us that after we believe we are "sealed with (the) Holy Spirit of promise" [Ephesians 1:13]. It is the ministry of the Holy Spirit to fill us with the love of God. The grammatical tense implies that the Holy Spirit filled our hearts in the past and still fills it today. Note God's love for us is not rationed drop by drop. On the contrary, the Holy Spirit sheds and pours it into the hearts of the redeemed.

The confidence we have in the day of judgment is not based only on our intellectual recognition of the fact of God's love, or even on the demonstration of God's love on the cross, but also on the inner, subjective certainty that God loves us. This is the point Paul is making when he affirmed that God's love has been "shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Spirit which is given unto us".

How can a believer glory in tribulation? Because we have a certain hope that is buoyed by the love of God that keeps us afloat. Whenever you are facing difficult circumstances remind yourself of the wondrous love of God at the cross and it will fill your heart with the strength it needs to patiently endure. This is our "anchor that keeps the soul steadfast and sure while the sea billows roll" [Priscilla J. Owens].
23 AUGUST.part7: There is no room for fear, anxiety, stress, and despair once the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts.

24 AUGUST.part4: For when we were yet without strength, in due time Christ died for the ungodly.
24 AUGUST.part5:
The Bible states clearly that we are God's enemies by nature. This enmity is expressed in our sinful rebellion against Him. The common view of this is that we are estranged from God, but He is not estranged from us. The hostility is all one-sided and that God goes on loving us with an unconditional love while we remain hateful toward Him. We tend to think God must love us for some reason within ourselves. But Scripture clearly says there is nothing in us to love. God is the One who loved us and gave us our salvation. We were not given salvation because we had earned it or worked for it.

The precious promise of God is that while we were weak and ungodly, without strength and hope, the Lord Jesus died for us who were dead in trespasses and sins. Yes, Jesus died for the ungodly. Jesus did not wait for us to get everything together and be somehow righteous before He was prepared to die for us. Our sins necessitated His sacrifice, and even before we truly understood that, Jesus paid the price to reverse our fallen condition.

Now eternally saved by grace, we can glory in the trials and tribulations of life which God uses to develop perseverance in us. We can only be in awe, as we realize the Lord gave up so much for the redemption of a people who deserve nothing at all. May we grasp the depth of our sin and thus better appreciate this Divine love for odious sinners.
24 AUGUST.part7: God loves the sinful, who are repentant and trusting Christ, and hates our sin.

25 AUGUST.part4: For when we were yet without strength, in due time Christ died for the ungodly.
25 AUGUST.part5:
When we consider the holy and righteous God and our unclean and rebellious character, we realize there is no reason why He should love us. Yet God has proven the depths of His love by sending His beloved Son, Jesus Christ, to deliver us from our sins by His blood, and then transform us progressively to be like Him in holiness and righteousness. The Lord Jesus' death on the cross is the ultimate expression of God's love for mankind: He sent His one and only Son into the world so we who are dead in sin might live through Him. This is love: not that we loved God, but that He loved us and gave His Son to be the atoning sacrifice for our sins.

The Cross of Calvary is the symbol of God's love. Words and songs may speak of this love, but it is the action of Jesus dying on the Cross that manifests the greatness of God's love for us. The desire and cry of every true believer's heart then is not only to apprehend the love of God more clearly, but to rest in it and be conformed more fully to it in their personal character and daily life.

You may have doubted God's love for you at some point in your life when you were faced with tough decisions, financial concerns, emotional and physical heartache or personal loss. Look to the Lord Jesus in faith and the Sun of righteousness will dispel the fog of doubt [Malachi 4:2].
25 AUGUST.part7: At Calvary, the love of God met the need of sinful man, and the ultimate price was paid for our redemption.

26 AUGUST.part2: Dying for a Friend - Human Love
26 AUGUST.part4: For scarcely for a righteous man will one die: yet peradventure for a good man some would even dare to die.
26 AUGUST.part5:
When the Lord Jesus confided in His disciples [John 15:14-15] about His impending persecution, desertion, crucifixion, death and resurrection, Peter's reply was, "I will lay down my life for thy sake," [John 13:37b] and "Likewise also said all the disciples" [Matthew 26:35b]. The love they had for the Lord was undeniably genuine and sincere but it was only human love. When He was arrested, they all forsook Him.

Love is a profound word but often loosely used. People casually say "I love this dish or ice-cream, that dress or shoes." In biblical Greek however, love is expressed in four different forms. Familial love is expressed as "storge"; love between husband and wife or romantic love, "eros"; friendship or brotherly love, "philia"; God's sacrificial love, "agape".

After His resurrection, Christ asked Peter, "lovest (agape) thou me ...?" to which Peter replied, "Yea, Lord; thou knowest that I love (philia) thee" [John 21:15]. Christ here spoke of agape but Peter replied with philia. He asked Peter again to his same reply. Christ asked the third time, "lovest (philia) thou me?" and Peter was grieved because Christ now spoke of a lesser love, philia.

Peter was unable to reciprocate the love his Lord had for him. Yet he was not rejected but given the commission to "feed my lambs" and "feed my sheep". God knows our limitations. "A bruised reed shall he not break, and smoking flax shall he not quench" [Matthew 12:20a]. Peter's love for Christ would grow as he continued in His love. And this reformed and restored disciple would finally give his life for His Master [John 21:18-19]. The greatest commandment still is to love God with all our heart, mind, soul and strength.
26 AUGUST.part7: We love Him, because He first loved us. - 1 John 4:19

27 AUGUST.part2: Dying for Your Enemy - Divine Love
27 AUGUST.part4: But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
27 AUGUST.part5:
Naturally, we love those who love us; we love those who do good to us. We are angry with, even hate those who intentionally seek to hurt us. To love those who love us is human; to hate those who love us is devilish; to love those who hate us is divine.

In the past, we were alienated from God and were His enemies by our wicked works. We broke every law of God, and the handwriting of ordinances was against us; the wrath of God was upon us, and a certain fearful looking for of judgment and fiery indignation awaits us. From divine justice's point of view, we deserve hell.

O helpless, hopeless sinner, how can we stand before a holy and just God who is angry with the wicked every day? Not only have we broken all His commandments, we broke His heart. We have often provoked Him to anger, wearied Him with our countless sins, grieved and quenched the Holy Spirit. Often, we resist the Holy Spirit's prompting and shut our ears to His tender voice. How shall we flee the wrath to come?

How is "love thine enemy" demonstrated in the Person of the God-man, Christ Jesus? He died for the ungodly, He took the sinners' place and drank the cup of God's wrath on their behalf because He loves them with a perfect love. He died for them; He lives for them; He is coming again for them. Before, condemned sinners and haters of God, now, beloved of God and lovers of Him.
27 AUGUST.part7: Amazing love! How can it be that Thou, my God, shouldst die for me?

28 AUGUST.part4: But God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us.
28 AUGUST.part5:
By man's tragic fall to sin, the greatness of God's love was fully manifested in the death of His Son Jesus Christ. We sometimes wish our first parents Adam and Eve had never sinned. Then life would be perfectly blissful for them and their descendants - free from sin, sickness, sorrow, misery and death. It would be heaven on earth. But then, we would only know the benevolent love of God. Who would have thought, not even the angels, that God would humble Himself, take on human flesh, live a sinless life, and offer Himself a sacrifice on behalf of fallen men that they might live again unto eternal life in God? Without controversy, great is the mystery of godliness!

Love is such a powerful force that it caused the omnipotent God to sacrifice Himself to save undeserving and unworthy sinners whom He loves. For love's sake, Christ was willing to suffer the humiliation of cruel men, mockery of sinners, scorn of the wicked, crucifixion by the ungodly. Charity suffereth long, and is kind ... beareth all things ... endureth all things [1 Corinthians 13:4, 7]. Here is love in its noblest form, love of every love the best! But where the curse of sin abounds, the love of God did much more abound!
28 AUGUST.part7: O matchless love! O love divine! It's length, and breadth, and height, and depth, Should shed abroad this heart of mine, Amazing love so strong as death! Come love of Christ, Inflame my heart, So sweet, unchanging and pure. How shall I from this love depart, unconditional and sure.   Could we with ink the ocean fill, ... and every man a scribe by trade. To write the love of God above, would drain the ocean dry. - Frederick M. Lehman

29 AUGUST.part4: Much more then, being now justified by His blood ...
29 AUGUST.part5:
Two keywords in Romans 5:9a are the focus of our meditation today. The first is "justified". Justification, as explained by John Calvin, is simply "the acceptance with which God receives us into his favour as righteous men" (John Calvin, Institutes of the Christian Religion). In a court of law, when an innocent man is wrongly accused of a crime and brought before a just judge, he will be judged according to his innocence and said to be "justified" before the judge. However, no sinner can find favour in God's eyes, because sin is an abomination to Him. Since no man is perfectly innocent of sin, no man can be justified before God.

This brings us to the second keyword, which is "blood". In this context, it is the blood of the Lord Jesus Christ. We are justified by Christ's blood, which He shed when He died on the cross. Blood represents life and death, and plays an important role in the Jewish rituals of cleansing and atonement for the people's sins. The blood of animals sacrificed in the temple signifies that a death had occurred in atonement and shows the way for transgressors to be reconciled to God. So, Christ would shed His blood and sacrifice His life to perfectly and fully atone for the sins of the world.

Are you troubled by the guilt of your sins? Look to Christ's sacrificial blood and come to God in faith. You will be justified in God's sight because Christ died and shed His blood for your sins.
29 AUGUST.part7: So Christ was once offered to bear the sins of many; and unto them that look for Him shall He appear the second time without sin unto salvation. - Hebrews 9:28

30 AUGUST.part4: ... we shall be saved from wrath through Him.
30 AUGUST.part5:
Our focus today is the fearful wrath of God, which in our referenced text says we, who have been justified, are saved from. God's wrath comes from His aversion to and displeasure against sin. It is manifested in the consequential calamities He metes out to the unrepentant. When Pharaoh hardened his heart and did not let the Hebrews go, God sent plagues to punish him. The Bible is full of examples that tell us how God deals with those who disobey Him, even the Jews. See for example, Ezekiel 22.

God's wrath is as real today as it was in biblical times. We all are born sinners, and from the moment of birth God's wrath is upon us [Ephesians 2:2-3]. Indeed, for all unrepentant sinners, God's wrath awaits the last day, when Christ will come to judge the world. This "wrath to come" [Matthew 3:7; Luke 3:7; 1 Thessalonians 1:10] is synonymous with the judgment of hell, reserved for all who do not repent of their sins and accept the offered way of salvation.

Dear readers, do not delay. If you are enjoying the pleasures of sin, know that it is but for a season, and there is a wrath to come, an eternity of hell to suffer for this brief period of sinful enjoyment. Repent now, confess your sins to the Lord Jesus Christ and ask Him to forgive and take away the guilt in your hearts. He died for your sins and rose again the third day to deliver you from the wrath to come.
30 AUGUST.part7: But if we walk in the light, as He is in the light, we have fellowship one with another, and the blood of Jesus Christ His Son cleanseth us from all sin. - 1 John 1:7

31 AUGUST.part4: For if, when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of His Son, much more, being reconciled, we shall be saved by His life.
31 AUGUST.part5: Granted that we cannot get along with everyone we meet in life, and there may be those we consider to be "enemies". They could be our good friends formerly who have offended or been offended by us, and now we refuse to fellowship or even make eye contact with. God and Adam had a perfect relationship until the day Adam sinned. Adam broke his commitment to God's command by eating the forbidden fruit. So, Adam and all humankind after him suffered a broken relationship with God. Now, only God can initiate reconciliation with man by dealing with Adam's sin. The sin of disobedience to God's Word continued from Adam to us today. The penalty for sin is death. However, God loved us and does not wish that anyone should die. "But (God) is longsuffering to us-ward, not willing that any should perish, but that all should come to repentance." [2 Peter 3:9] God in His mercy and grace sent His Son Jesus to pay the penalty of man's sin. Being fully man, the Incarnate Christ could represent sinful mankind like us. But He is also fully God and therefore sinless. He is the only One qualified to be the perfect and acceptable atoning sacrifice for our sins by dying on our behalf. Those who trust in Him are reconciled with God. To be reconciled is to have fellowship with God. Since God is eternal, we too will have eternal life. We can live because the Lord Jesus died for us.
31 AUGUST.part7: For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so by the obedience of one shall many be made righteous. - Romans 5:19

1 SEPTEMBER.part4: For if, when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of His Son, much more, being reconciled, we shall be saved by His life.
1 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Would you do anything to save one who was your enemy? Because of our sins, we were enemies with God who is holy. Sin and holiness are like water and oil. The two cannot mix. In our sinful state therefore, God can have no relationship with us. But out of love, He sent His Son, the Lord Jesus to die as the payment for our sins. This is the only way to make reconciliation between the holy God and sinful man.

Jesus as the Son of God was obedient to the Father. He knew His mission was to come into the world to die for sinful mankind. As a man, Jesus endured all the hardships of physical life. He felt hunger, sorrow and was acquainted with all the emotions we experience. He worked as a man and fully understood the temptations and difficulties we face in life. He knows our weaknesses and fears. Yet He was without sin. As a man, Jesus could represent us and take our penalty. As God, He could obey and keep perfectly the whole Law of God.

God accepted this "offering lamb" in Jesus to atone for our sins because Jesus is the perfect man. He obeyed God to the very end to die on the cross. He took over our sins. On His account, we are free from its penalty and God counts all who believe in His Son to be absolved from guilt. We who were once enemies of God are now reconciled through His death on the cross and His resurrection from the grave. No more enemies but children of God in Christ Jesus.
1 SEPTEMBER.part7: For Christ also hath once suffered for sins, the just for the unjust, that he might bring us to God, being put to death in the flesh, but quickened by the Spirit. - 1 Peter 3:18

2 SEPTEMBER.part4: And not only so, but we also joy in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom we have now received the atonement.
2 SEPTEMBER.part5:
What are the remarkable benefits for those whom God has declared righteous by faith in Him? Not only are we justified by the blood of Christ, not only are we saved by Christ from God's wrath, but we are also reconciled to Him. Our relationship with the holy God is transformed. We no longer fear Him as a distant, frightening figure who is impossible to please.

To grasp how wondrous Paul's declaration is, just recall the time you were in bitter argument with someone. It was difficult even to be in the same room with them. Our hearts were twisted in anger at the very thought of them. "Reconciliation" is when two such estranged persons forgive each other. The relationship is not only restored but can now develop into one where both enjoy each other's presence.

Similarly, we were separated bitterly from God while we did not have faith in Christ. Our dispute with Him was no simple human quarrel. God is holy, pure and perfect, and He hates sin [Isaiah 6:3; Psalm 5:4]. As sinners, we were like filthy rags before God [Isaiah 64:6]. To make things right between us and God, Christ had to die on the cross, bearing the wrath of God against sin. Thus, while we are still imperfect, Paul tells us that by our faith in Jesus Christ we have now received the atonement.

In Christ, we are saved and safe because we are now reconciled with God and will forevermore be.
2 SEPTEMBER.part7: The LORD is my strength and song, and is become my salvation. The voice of rejoicing and salvation is in the tabernacles of the righteous: the right hand of the LORD doeth valiantly. [Psalm 118:14-15].

3 SEPTEMBER.part4: And not only so, but we also joy in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom we have now received the atonement.
3 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Once a year on the Day of Atonement, the high priest would enter the inner sanctum of the Holy Temple in Jerusalem to perform a complex ceremony to ask God's forgiveness on behalf of all Israel [Leviticus 16]. A scapegoat would be chosen to be presented alive before God, "to make an atonement with him", and then it would be released into the wilderness bearing the sins of the people, who would then be clean from all their sins before God [Leviticus 16:8-10, 16-29]. This annual cycle would go on. Atonement through ritual sacrifice was of temporary and limited effectiveness and had to be repeated again and again by the priests.

In contrast, when the Lord Jesus Christ died for us on the cross, He "offered one sacrifice for sins for ever" and then gloriously "sat down on the right hand of God" [Hebrews 10:10, 12]. The Day of Atonement in Leviticus 16 foreshadowed and anticipated a greater, permanent cleansing of God's people which would be accomplished by the one and forever sacrifice of a perfect high priest - Christ.

When we wrong someone, we are expected to make amends or face retribution. In response, we try to remedy the situation and make it up to the other person. With God, we who ought to bear the punishment for our sins are let off scot-free, because Christ, the God-incarnate, took our place as the perfect, permanent sacrifice. Through His atonement, we are reconciled forever with God.
3 SEPTEMBER.part7: Jesus my great High Priest, Offered His blood and died; My guilty conscience seeks, No sacrifice beside. His powerful blood did once atone, And now it pleads before the Throne. - Isaac Watts

4 SEPTEMBER.part4: Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned:
4 SEPTEMBER.part5:
When Russian president Putin declared war on Ukraine, many ordinary Russians who did not agree with him suffered the consequences. Economic sanctions by Western countries caused hardship for the people. Russian soldiers suffered and died in the fighting. "It's so unfair" they may say. Because of one man's decision, the whole country suffers. But those are the 'rules' of government and politics. It is based on the representative principle. This principle is clearly taught in the answer to Question 16 of the Westminster Shorter Catechism: "The covenant being made with Adam, not only for himself, but for his posterity; all mankind, descending from him by ordinary generation, sinned in him, and fell with him, in his first transgression."

Paul states it very simply in our text; "as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin". God warned Adam not to eat of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, saying; "for in the day that thou eatest thereof thou shalt surely die" [Genesis 2:17]. But Adam, our first parent disobeyed. Theologians call his transgression the Original Sin, which is defined as "that moral corruption in which every human being is born with, and it consists of both the judicial guilt and the actual corruption of humanity which results from Adam's sin".

Yes, we are all sinners, and as sinners, we have to suffer its consequences. The Bible tells us "the wages of sin is death" [Romans 6:23]; but thank God the same verse also says "but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord."
4 SEPTEMBER.part7: Fear nothing but to sin. This should be every believer's motto. - James Smith, Daily Remembrancer

5 SEPTEMBER.part4: Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned:
5 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Note this significant fact: a man is not condemned to death because of Adam's sin. Scripture clearly says: "Death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned." A man dies because of his own sins, not his father's. Every man is personally responsible to God. The phrase, "all have sinned" does not merely mean that all men have sinned at some time or other, but that all sinned representatively when Adam sinned. John Owen, in his book The Holy Spirit: His Gifts and Power, explains it this way: "Sin is either original or actual. Original sin is the habitual inconformity of our natures to the holiness of God, expressed in the law of creation. Actual sin is in our inconformity to God and His holiness, expressed in the particular commands of the law." To put it simply, we have all been born with a sin nature, and we all sin.

There are many verses in the Bible attesting to this indisputable fact. Here are a few: "For there is no man that sinneth not" [1 Kings 8:46]; "Who can say, I have made my heart clean, I am pure from my sin?" [Proverbs 20:9]; "The heart is deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked: who can know it?" [Jeremiah 17:9]; "For there is not a just man upon earth, that doeth good, and sinneth not." [Ecclesiastes 7:20].

Understanding this simple truth should cause us all to cry out in desperation as the Philippian jailer did, "What must I do to be saved?" [Acts 16:30]
5 SEPTEMBER.part7: And they said, Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and thou shalt be saved, and thy house. - Acts 16:31

6 SEPTEMBER.part4: Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned:
6 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Just as God had warned, when Adam disobeyed God, he died; first spiritually, and then, physically. But it did not end there: it affected the entire creation, the whole earth, all living things and most crucially, all his descendants. Louis Berkhof explains it this way in his Systematic Theology.

"As result of the fall, the father of the race could only pass on a depraved human nature to his offspring. From that unholy source, sin flows on as an impure stream to all the generations of men, polluting everyone and everything with which it comes in contact. It is exactly this state of things that made the question of job so pertinent, 'Who can bring a clean thing out of an unclean? not one' [Job 14:4]."

Today, every one of us lives with the consequences of Adam's sin. We possess a sin nature and struggle daily with sin. The Apostle Paul describes his frustration in Romans 7:14-25; a frustration every Christian can identify with. Our sinful flesh refuses to respond to the requirements of God's Law. Those things which we as Christians despise, we find ourselves doing. Those things which we as Christians desire, we fail to accomplish. No matter how much we may wish to serve God in our minds, we find ourselves sinning in our bodies. Like the Apostle, we cry out; "O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?" [Romans 7:24]. But we thank God for providing the answer to that question in the person of the Lord Jesus Christ, the Second Adam.
6 SEPTEMBER.part7: As the salt flavours every drop in the Atlantic, so does sin affect every atom of our nature. - Charles H. Spurgeon

7 SEPTEMBER.part4: For until the law sin was in the world: but sin is not imputed when there is no law.
7 SEPTEMBER.part5:
"Sin is not imputed when there is no law." Theoretically, this is correct. Since sin is a violation of law, people cannot be held guilty unless there is a law which they knowingly violate. But sin and death existed long before the giving of the Moral Law in Exodus 20. People know innately that they have sinned against God when they commit certain acts. For example, Joseph rejected the advances of Potiphar's wife saying; "how then can I do this great wickedness, and sin against God" [Genesis 39:9]. Similarly, when the men of Sodom demanded that Lot handed over the two angels who were with him, he pleaded with them to "do not so wickedly" [Genesis 19:7]. Both Joseph and Lot lived long before Moses gave the commandment against adultery and taught the people that homosexuality was an abomination in God's eyes.

"For until the law sin was in the world". All have sinned, because sin was always in the world, not only after the law was given by Moses, but also before. So sin was imputed or charged upon man even before Moses' time, and death passed upon all.

Tragically, we live in an age where people knowingly violate the Law of God. They call good evil, and evil good. For example, in so-called Christian societies like Canada, America and Great Britain, anyone who dares to call homosexuality a sin is labelled as hateful and punishable by law. Some pastors even solemnize same-sex marriages in their churches. May the Lord protect us and our children in this wicked and perverse generation.
7 SEPTEMBER.part7: Wherefore come out from among them, and be ye separate, saith the Lord, and touch not the unclean thing; and I will receive you. - 2 Corinthians 6:17

8 SEPTEMBER.part4: Nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over them that had not sinned after the similitude of Adam's transgression, who is the figure of him that was to come.
8 SEPTEMBER.part5:
The phrase "death reigned" and a variation of it appear three times in Romans chapter 5: "death reigned from Adam to Moses" in verse 14; death reigned "by one man's offence" verse 17; and "sin hath reigned unto death" verse 21. The repetition implies the importance of this concept for understanding the passage.

By saying that "death reigned", Paul is not only reiterating the point that death is universal, but also emphasizing the power death holds over mankind. Like an absolute monarch, death rules over all with complete authority. All are subject to death because all have sinned. God's holiness and justice require all sinners to be punished with death.

The phrase "death reigned' also suggests that death can be defeated. Since the reign of death is a result of God's judgment for sin, the power of sin and death would be overcome when God's justice is satisfied. Indeed, God's justice was satisfied in Christ - by His suffering and death as a substitute for sinners. For those who trust in Christ as their Lord and Saviour, the penalty for their sins has been fully paid for by His atoning death.

For believers, although our bodies will still die, sin and death have no power over us. We triumph over sin in this life because we have spiritual life in Christ. When Christ returns, death will be destroyed [1 Corinthians 15:26]. The bodies of the dead shall be resurrected and all who are in Christ shall enjoy eternal life with Him.
8 SEPTEMBER.part7: Forasmuch then as the children are partakers of flesh and blood, he also himself likewise took part of the same; that through death he might destroy him that had the power of death, that is, the devil. And deliver them who through fear of death were all their lifetime subject to bondage. - Hebrews 2:14-15

9 SEPTEMBER.part4: Nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over them that had not sinned after the similitude of Adam's transgression, who is the figure of him that was to come.
9 SEPTEMBER.part5:
In verse 14, Paul links the reign of death to a specific time period: "from Adam to Moses". But death reigns over all men and over all time periods. Whether they live in the past, present or future, they die. So why does Paul specify a time period for death's reign?

Here, Paul is not limiting the reign of death to a specific period, but highlighting the fact that people died even during the time between Adam and Moses. What is so special about that period? It is the period before the law was given to Moses. Earlier in verse 13, Paul makes it clear that no one can be accused of violating the law if the law does not exist. So even though the people of that period actually sinned, sin could not be counted against them because the law had not been given to them. Consequently, they could not be subjected to death. They had not sinned like Adam who disobeyed a direct commandment of God. But still, they died - not for their personal transgressions, but for the sin of Adam, who represented all men in his sin.

For believers, our sins are also not counted against us but for a different reason. Our sins have been imputed to the Lord Jesus Christ, who took upon Himself the full punishment that we deserve for our sins. This does not give us the license to sin as much as we want. Death continues to be a sombre reminder of the gravity of sin, and this should guide us in how we should live.
9 SEPTEMBER.part7: Let us hear the conclusion of the whole matter: Fear God, and keep his commandments: for this is the whole duty of man. For God shall bring every work into judgment, with every secret thing, whether it be good, or whether it be evil. - Ecclesiastes 12:13-14

10 SEPTEMBER.part4: Nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over them that had not sinned after the similitude of Adam's transgression, who is the figure of him that was to come.
10 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Death is no respecter of persons. Regardless of one's age, race, religion, and social status, all must die. Knowing that we will all die someday, what is your attitude towards death?

Some accept death as a natural and inevitable part of life. Some are fatalistic, thinking that death comes as it wills; there is nothing they can do to delay it. Others deny death's inevitability. They go to great lengths to defeat this enemy - through diets, fitness programs, health spas, nutritional supplements, and a host of programs and procedures to enhance their physical and mental well-being. Whether a person accepts or denies death, few face it without a tinge of fear. And for those who have been robbed of their loved ones, few have not been struck by pain and grief.

What should the Christian's attitude towards death be? Christians defy death. While death is inevitable for all, it is by no means natural. Death is not part of God's design for man at creation, but the result of God's judgment upon all for the sin of Adam [Romans 5:12]. And God provides the solution. He sent His only Son, the Lord Jesus, to take the punishment for our sins. Jesus suffered and died in our place and rose again. Because of His resurrection, all who believe in Him will have the blessed hope of bodily resurrection and eternal life. So, although Christians also die physically, death and sin no longer have power over us, for the Lord Jesus Christ has conquered death.
10 SEPTEMBER.part7: O death, where is thy sting? O grave, where is thy victory? The sting of death is sin; and the strength of sin is the law. But thanks be to God, which giveth us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ. - 1 Corinthians 15:55-57

11 SEPTEMBER.part4: Nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over them that had not sinned after the similitude of Adam's transgression, who is the figure of him that was to come.
11 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Paul describes Adam as "the figure of him that was to come". The word "figure" is translated from the Greek word typos. The original meaning of typos is a mark made as a result of a blow or pressure, like the marks made by the nails on the hands of the risen Christ [John 20:25]. Later, typos took on a wider range of meanings. It can mean a person, object or event that typified or prefigured something besides itself, just as Adam is a "type" or "figure" of the One who was to come, that is the Lord Jesus Christ. Through Adam, we see glimpses of truths that would be fully revealed later in Christ.

Adam is not the only "type" of Christ. On the road to Emmaus, Jesus explained to two disciples what was said in "all the Scriptures" concerning Himself [Luke 24:27]. This means that the Old Testament, in one way or another, points to Christ. For example, Solomon, a great teacher of wisdom, prefigures Christ, the greatest teacher of wisdom. The raising of the brazen serpent foreshadows Christ's death on the cross.

Typology underscores the sovereignty and immutability of God. God directs history in such a way that the past foreshadows the future. There is an unbroken continuity in His redemptive plan; we can trust Him to bring His purposes to pass. We can also find comfort in knowing God is not capricious or random but will deal with us in the same way as He dealt with people in the past.
11 SEPTEMBER.part7: The counsel of the LORD standeth for ever, the thoughts of his heart to all generations. - Psalm 33:11

12 SEPTEMBER.part4: Nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over them that had not sinned after the similitude of Adam's transgression, who is the figure of him that was to come.
12 SEPTEMBER.part5:
It may seem strange that Adam is described as a figure of Christ. How can sinful Adam be said to represent Jesus Christ, the sinless Son of God? In what ways are they similar?

Adam parallels Christ in several important ways. First, they were both appointed by God to be representatives of humanity. Paul calls them the "first Adam" and "last Adam" respectively, suggesting that there are only two representative heads for humanity [1 Corinthians 15:45]. The entire human race is split into two based on the individual's relationship with them. Adam represents the old humanity: those lost in sin who stand in rebellion against God. Christ is the head of the new humanity: those who have been redeemed and saved by Christ. With each of them, God made a covenant - the covenant of works with Adam and the covenant of grace with Christ. Both covenants are centred on their obedience to God. As heads of their respective covenants, the effect of their obedience or disobedience is passed on to all whom they represent.

Some may think it unjust that all mankind should be condemned because of their representative's personal decision to disobey. But what makes us think we can do better than Adam who was created in a state of sinlessness and lived in a sinless world? Rather, it is precisely through this principle of covenant headship that God brings forth His most precious gift of saving grace to all His people - for in Christ we attain the righteousness we could never earn on our own.
12 SEPTEMBER.part7: Paul speaks of Adam and Christ as if there had never been anyone else in the world; for these two men have all other people hanging from their belts. - Thomas Goodwin

13 SEPTEMBER.part4: Nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over them that had not sinned after the similitude of Adam's transgression, who is the figure of him that was to come.
13 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Typology in the Bible is concerned with how Old Testament patterns prefigure those in the New Testament. Their similarities are usually in view. In Romans chapter 5, however, Paul uses typology not only to bring out the similarities in the overall pattern between Adam and Christ, but also to highlight their profound differences. It is in these differences that the incomparable glories of Christ and His works are made manifest.

Adam was the first man to be created - formed out of dust and made a living soul. Adam was given dominion over all creatures. He was to rule over and care for God's creation. By his disobedience, he brought a curse upon creation, and sin and death to all men as their representative. In Adam, there is only judgment and condemnation.

Christ was described as the last Adam and a life-giving spirit [1 Corinthians 15:45]. Although He is God, He condescended Himself to be born into this world and took upon Himself the full punishment for the sins of all His people. By His perfect obedience and atoning death, He brings forgiveness of sins and eternal life to all who believe in Him. In Christ, there is justification and abundance of grace.

Are you in Adam or in Christ? No doubt, we are all in Adam. He represents the whole human race. But for those who believe and follow Christ, we have been justified by grace and are new creatures in Christ. Old things are passed away and all things are become new [2 Corinthians 5:17].
13 SEPTEMBER.part7: For as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive. - 1 Corinthians 15:22

14 SEPTEMBER.part4: But not as the offence, so also is the free gift. For if through the offence of one many be dead, much more the grace of God, and the gift by grace, which is by one man, Jesus Christ, hath abounded unto many.
14 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Adam's offence happened when he placed his will above God's. Because of his transgression, the whole human race after him fell under the dominion of sin. God could have left us to perish in darkness since mankind is merely suffering what he deserves. Yet God did not let us meet our natural and deserved end. He saved us through a supernatural divine plan - He sent His only begotten Son to this natural world to take on the punishment of our sin, and to offer eternal life freely to whosoever believes in Him.

Offence is an act of man, but salvation is the will of God. God has given us a gift which we do not deserve - this is God's gift to us by His grace. On the one hand, man's offence against God speaks of his pride and presumptuousness, on the other, God's gift to man tells of His love and grace. There is a gulf of difference between the fall of all mankind through the First Adam and the salvation of a remnant through the Second.

There may also be an inclination for us to equate the two "many" in this verse. If through the offence of one, many (not all) be dead, is it therefore true to say that some do not suffer from the consequences of original sin? The full counsel of scripture tells us this is not the case. "Many" in this verse is not quantitative. This verse is not telling us that a great but finite number had fallen, and the same great and finite number will be made right given God's grace. Paul here is merely explaining how, though the entire human race had fallen because of one man's sin, yet the free gift of grace was offered to all whom God has chosen to receive.
14 SEPTEMBER.part7: In that day shall the Lord of hosts be for a crown of glory, and for a diadem of beauty, unto the residue of His people. - Isaiah 28:5

15 SEPTEMBER.part2: Judgment  by One Sin; Salvation for Many
15 SEPTEMBER.part4: And not as it was by one that sinned, so is the gift: for the judgment was by one to condemnation, but the free gift is of many offences unto justification.
15 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Sin falls largely into two categories: "original sin" and "actual sins". Original sin is the sin we inherited from Adam, whereas actual sins are the sins we commit every day in our thoughts, words and actions. In a way, we can say original sin leads to actual sins. After Adam ate from the tree of knowledge of good and evil (the original sin), the human race fell from a state of being "able to sin but also able not to sin" to one of being "not able not to sin". In this wretched depraved condition, we commit numerous actual sins.

Today's verse highlights the difference between these two kinds of sin. Because of Adam's first sin, the human race suffered condemnation. But after that particular sin, Adam would continue to commit actual sins, as do His descendants. Yet when the Lord Jesus Christ came into this world to die for our sins, He died for both our original sin and our actual ones. Thus, we see a great difference between the works of Adam and that of Christ: Adam caused the whole mankind to fall by one sin, whereas our Lord died not only to save us from the original sin, but also the effects of it - for the many offences committed by the human race after Adam's first sin.

A common question asked is: "Since Jesus died for our actual sins, why should we still confess them and ask for His forgiveness every day?" The answer is this: "Our Lord died for all our sins - past, present and future - and if we come before Him to confess them, God will forgive us because of what Jesus has already done for us on the cross. God will be faithful to the covenant He has with us through our Saviour."
15 SEPTEMBER.part7: If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness. - 1 John 1:9

16 SEPTEMBER.part2: The Reign of Death and Life
16 SEPTEMBER.part4: For if by one man's offence death reigned by one; much more they which receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness shall reign in life by one, Jesus Christ.
16 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Death reigned over humanity since man's fall to sin. All in Adam are spiritually lost and condemned to physical and spiritual death. Here the apostle Paul contrasts the reign of death with the reign of life.

"For if by one man's offence death reigned by one." This thought is repeated in several different ways in the preceding and succeeding verses: "Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death passed upon all men, for that all have sinned" [v. 12]; "For if through the offence of one many be dead' [v. 15]; "the judgment was by one to condemnation" [v. 16]; "by the offence of one judgment came upon all men to condemnation" [v. 18]; "For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners" [v. 19]. Paul establishes the causal connection between what Adam did and the sinfulness of all people throughout all time. In Adam, the reign of death.

But now the gift of righteousness reigns in life through God's abundant grace to those who are justified by Jesus Christ who has freed them from the condemnation they are in. "The grace of God, and the gift by grace, which is by one man, Jesus Christ, hath abounded unto many" [v. 15]; "So by the obedience of one shall many be made righteous" [v. 19]. In Christ, the reign of life!

Life here is opposed to death and expresses the state of our existence, both now and hereafter. God's ultimate gift is life eternal after our bodies die and an endless perfect communion with God. Which would you choose: death or life?
16 SEPTEMBER.part7: O LORD, my most high God, help me to humbly acknowledge Thy supreme reign in life, and to give all thanks and glory to Thee.

17 SEPTEMBER.part4: For if by one man's offence death reigned by one; much more they which receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness shall reign in life by one, Jesus Christ.
17 SEPTEMBER.part5:
The apostle Paul attributes our salvation to God's grace - "To the praise of the glory of His grace, wherein He hath made us accepted in the beloved. In whom we have redemption through His blood, the forgiveness of sins, according to the riches of His grace" [Ephesians 1:6-7]. Paul further says, "For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God"[Ephesians 2:8]. In his letter to Titus, Paul again emphasizes this amazing and gracious work of God: "For the grace of God that bringeth salvation hath appeared to all men" [Titus 2:11]. Salvation is the gift of God by His grace. In fact, it is the gift of His grace.

The Greek word for 'grace' is charis, meaning 'favour'. Grace is the act of conferring favour upon one who does not deserve it. Grace is unmerited and given at the giver's discretion.

Grace is defined as 'the free and unmerited favour of God as manifested in the salvation of sinners and the bestowal of undeserved blessings, divine assistance given to humans for their regeneration or sanctification.' God's grace is absolutely free and amazing; it is that which conquers sin both in its penalty and its power [Romans 5:12-21; 6:1-23].

To quote John Piper, "Grace is the enabling of God not to sin; grace is power, not just pardon." May we let God's enabling grace work in our lives till this same amazing grace leads us home to glory!
17 SEPTEMBER.part7: Amazing Grace, how sweet the sound That saved a wretch like me. I once was lost, but now am found, Was blind but now I see. - John Newton

18 SEPTEMBER.part4: For if by one man's offence death reigned by one; much more they which receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness shall reign in life by one, Jesus Christ.
18 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Sin and death reigned over humanity because of the trespasses of one man - Adam. However, that power has been abolished. Grace overturns the consequences of sin and life triumphs over death "by one, Jesus Christ". Our Lord Jesus has overturned the act of Adam. Through one Man, Jesus Christ, the abundance of grace and the gift of righteousness reign in life.

In this verse, Paul speaks of two gifts which God gives us through His Son Jesus Christ - God's abundant provision of grace and His gift of righteousness. We do not deserve, and could not earn God's favour, yet He has abundantly blessed us with His grace. The reign of grace includes deliverance from the penalty of sin (justification), deliverance from the power of sin (transformation and sanctification through fellowship and growth with God) and deliverance finally from the presence of sin (translation into His eternal presence in our glorification).

Righteousness means rightness of relationship and rightness of life. "That as sin hath reigned unto death, even so might grace reign through righteousness unto eternal life by Jesus Christ our Lord" [v. 21]. The abundance of grace is specified as 'the gift of righteousness' [Romans 1:17; 3:22- 23; Philippians 3:9]. Therefore it is a righteousness which comes through faith alone, a righteousness which justifies. It is the objective imputed righteousness of the Lord Jesus Christ, which is the covering for believing sinners [Isaiah 61:10].
18 SEPTEMBER.part7: O LORD, thank You for Your abundant grace, which You have freely given us through Your beloved Son, Jesus Christ. Use us in proclaiming Your gift of grace and righteousness to those in need of eternal salvation.

19 SEPTEMBER.part4: Therefore as by the offence of one judgment came upon all men to condemnation; even so by the righteousness of one the free gift came upon all men unto justification of life.
19 SEPTEMBER.part5:
As the offence of the first Adam led to a pronouncement of death upon all humans, Paul here writes that the righteousness of the Second Adam has led to a pronouncement of eternal life for those who believe in Him. Justification refers to man being pronounced righteous and just, and deserving of eternal life. This pronouncement is made not because of anything we did, rather, we can be declared righteous because of the Lord Jesus Christ, the second Adam, who paid our penalty and made it possible.

Now declared righteous, how do we live our lives? Are we still choked by the cares of this world and continuing in our habitual sins? Are we making an effort to show forth Christ in our lives? If we are righteous in Him, then the way we live must show that we have His likeness. Let us strive for a godly hatred of sin. Let us declare the righteousness of Christ in a way which humbles ourselves and exalts God.

Let the justified not continue in their sinful ways. When we inadvertently fall into sin, let us also not be discouraged. Remember we already have the victory of eternal life. We are now dead to sin and have the strength and ability to overcome our sinful ways because the Holy Spirit who indwells us is Immanuel "God with us" and our helper. The true child of the thrice holy God cannot stop striving for holiness.
19 SEPTEMBER.part7: Remember, "Therefore being justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ." [Romans 5:1]

20 SEPTEMBER.part4: For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so by the obedience of one shall many be made righteous.
20 SEPTEMBER.part5:
The more we realize our human weakness, the more amazing and awe-inspiring Christ's life on earth will be to us. The idea in Romans 5 is that we are righteous because when God the Father looks at us, He sees Christ's righteousness imputed on us. We have been declared righteous because Christ lived a righteous life, and this sinless life of perfect righteousness has been imputed to us. When we examine ourselves, we can see how difficult, even impossible, it is to live a life of perfect obedience to God. Often in thought, word and deed, we sin without even realising it!

When the Lord Jesus Christ was on Earth, He demonstrated not just perfect obedience to God in following and obeying the letter of the law as the hypocritical Pharisees did, but also the spirit of it which was impossible for man to do. His standard of obedience was a divine standard unachievable by anyone else. (Read Matthew 5:21-48).

Are we appropriately thankful that Christ lived the perfect life of obedience on our behalf ? Think about the "little" sins we commit. How often we deceive ourselves thinking "it is just a small thing". In the searchlight of Christ's perfect obedience, our attitude towards these "little sins" must change.

As we strive day by day to live a life pleasing to our Lord, we appreciate the impossibility of our task in our frail carnal bodies in this sin-cursed world. Therefore, have a heart of utmost gratitude to the One who has done it for us.
20 SEPTEMBER.part7: Take time to be holy, be calm in thy soul, Each thought and each motive beneath His control. Thus led by His Spirit to fountains of love, Thou soon shalt be fitted for service above. - William D Longstaff

21 SEPTEMBER.part4: For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so by the obedience of one shall many be made righteous.
21 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Many confuse grace and justice. Often, you will hear atheists argue that they do not want to believe in the Christian God because it is unjust that He has chosen some to be saved and left others to eternal damnation. However, let us better understand these two attributes of God's character - justice and grace.

Justice is getting one's just desserts. If we were to abide strictly by the principle of justice, God, who is just is perfectly justified in condemning us all to eternal death - for all have sinned and the wages of sin is death.

Yet, He is also full of grace. Grace is the unmerited giving to us of something we do not deserve. No one deserves eternal life. But it is God's prerogative to grant eternal life to whoever He chooses. Just because God chose to extend His grace to some does not make Him any less just.

In the sinner's salvation, both attributes of God are fully met.

In Romans 5:19, we further read about the extent of God's grace. The Christian religion is different from any other because it is the only religion where eternal life is presented as a free gift to all. We can do nothing to earn it. It is all of grace. No action of ours can add or subtract a day to the amount of "life" we get. It is eternal because it has already been earned on our behalf by another - our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ.
21 SEPTEMBER.part7: He left His Father's throne above, So free, so infinite His grace; Humbled Himself in matchless love, And bled for Adam's helpless race; 'Tis mercy all, immense and free; For, O my God, it found out me. - Charles Wesley

22 SEPTEMBER.part4: Moreover the law entered, that the offence might abound ...
22 SEPTEMBER.part5:
As believers who love and fully trust in the Lord Jesus, we may find it perplexing why the law is so important in God's written Word. We may have expected this in the Old Testament, but here in the New Testament the Greek word for "law" appears 197 times, of which 75 are in the book of Romans. Why spill so much ink over this when Christ has already come?

The law is God's manual for living our lives according to His will and plan. When we purchase a washing machine, we read its manual first, so we know how to operate it. Otherwise, we may wash our delicate clothing using the "intensive" cycle and cause them damage. Likewise, without the law to guide, we will not be able to properly distinguish between right and wrong because the human heart is deceptive and evil.

The law is also God's 'guard rail' as we navigate the narrow path on this side of heaven. In Bunyan's "Pilgrim's Progress", Christian was to walk on the path along the fence and not cross over it. The law acts the same way. It teaches us the fundamentals of Christian living so that we do not end up on the wrong side.

Beloved, the law is there for our good. Although it may look demanding and stringent, just take a step back and look at the loving Father who gave you this law so that you can live and enjoy a life as that of a tree planted by rivers of living water, and whatsoever you do will prosper.
22 SEPTEMBER.part7: Have you been following God's guard rail all your life? Or have you wandered away from the path?

23 SEPTEMBER.part2: Purpose of the Law - Conviction of Sin
23 SEPTEMBER.part4: Moreover the law entered, that the offence might abound ...
23 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Today we dig a little deeper on the purpose for the law and why it is still relevant for the modern day Christian. Why do we need the law if Christ has already fulfilled the law for us?

The law is needful, because without it, we will have nothing to teach and convict us of sin. It is an important tool in God's arsenal to allow us to enjoy and appreciate what Christ died for. Our sinful hearts cry: "If there is nothing to tell us how bad we are, we must be good! Therefore, we do not need God at all."

If there is no conviction, we are left unaware of our sin and will not realise we need a Saviour until it is too late. Christ came to save sinners and the law enables us to realise we are indeed sinners, so that we may run to Him and seek forgiveness. The law makes the fragrance of Christ's work on the cross smell even sweeter. It allows us to see with clear lenses why there are scars on Christ's hands and feet.

As we compare our lives with the law and realise how much we are like 'open sepulchres', we will greatly appreciate God's grace, and worship Him with endless thanks and praise for He is the merciful God who is more than worthy of all our praise.

Beloved, recognise the gravity of your sins, but realise that the Lord Jesus Christ came to die for them.
23 SEPTEMBER.part7: Are you unaware of any sins in your life? Pray regularly for the Holy Spirit to reveal them to you so you can repent.

24 SEPTEMBER.part4: Moreover the law entered, that the offence might abound. But where sin abounded, grace did much more abound.
24 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Sin is deadly business and we all sin. Right after a time and act of sin, the Accuser comes alongside and whispers in our ears: "Wow you're horrible! How could you do that? Your family is better off without you. Your church does not need you! You are not indispensable. Your friends don't love and care for you anymore. Why would they waste time with such a hopeless person like you? You can never change!" And if the grief of committing the sin was not enough, we now have to deal with the 'half-truths' and accusations of the devil.

Paul tells us today that no matter how grievous, socially unacceptable, how hurtful your sins were, the grace of God surpasses them all. Do not believe the lies of the devil! Do not succumb to the temptation of giving up hope just because you have transgressed. Instead, turn your eyes upon the cross and the Lord Jesus Christ. Examine His nail- pierced hands and gaze on the scars which your sins have caused. There are scars which testify that Christ has already paid for your sins, past, present and future.

Despite the gravity of our sins, none is too great for the cross. There, Christ drank the full cup of God's wrath so that we instead may partake the cup of blessing. No sin is so great that the blood of Christ cannot cover.

If and when we sin, repent immediately, stop sinning and seek God's grace to abound in your life. Do not wallow in sin and self-pity. Instead, get up and live for Him who has paid it all for you.
24 SEPTEMBER.part7: Recognise the deception of the devil and realise God's over-abounding grace for you.

25 SEPTEMBER.part4: That as sin hath reigned unto death, even so might grace reign through righteousness unto eternal life by Jesus Christ our Lord.
25 SEPTEMBER.part5:
We read in verse 20 the purpose of the law. It convicts us of our sin and depravity, so that we can turn to God for help. And this is where God's grace comes in - where sin abounds, God's grace much more abounds, if man will only repent and turn to God for His bountiful provision. Today's verse is linked to verse 20 with the conjunction "that". In Greek, it is the word hina, which can also be translated "so that" or "in order that". Paul hereby transits from the purpose of the Law to that of God's grace.

What stands out in verse 21 is the word "reign". Without God, we live in the darkness of sin. Sin corrupts our every faculty. Our eyes are blinded to truth. Our minds cannot think beyond the finitude of what we can see. Our hearts are held captive to our lusts and pride. But all these belong to the past because of what the Lord Jesus has done on the cross for us. We are reconciled to God the Father. The Spirit of God indwells and strengthens everyone who comes to the Father through His Son. Sin no longer has dominion over us, for our Lord Jesus not only paid the penalty for our trespasses, but he has also granted us the power to overcome sin.
