And the good news is, the battle has already been won. If we trust in Jesus Christ to be our Saviour, then He must also be our Lord to reign over every part of our lives and thereby God will grant us strength to lead victorious and abundant lives for His glory.
25 SEPTEMBER.part7: All things are delivered unto me of my Father: and no man knoweth the Son, but the Father; neither knoweth any man the Father, save the Son, and he to whomsoever the Son will reveal him. Come unto me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest. - Matthew 11:27-28

26 SEPTEMBER.part4: That as sin hath reigned unto death, even so might grace reign through righteousness unto eternal life by Jesus Christ our Lord.
26 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Because of Christ's finished work on the cross, God the Father will not withhold His grace from anyone who comes before Him in the name of His Son. This not only speaks of God's love for us, it also reminds us God is faithful to His promises. He will not leave or forsake any of His children.

This to a certain extent could also be said of our earthly parents. We hear stories of parents who love their children so much they are willing to sacrifice all they have for them. However, there is a limit to what a parent can give. As much as a parent loves the child, they cannot be with them every moment of his life; their understanding of the children's troubles is also limited by their own ability to empathize. But this cannot be said of God. Our God is with us now and forever, and He has promised every one of His children He will be with us. Every time we ask for His strength, He will provide. He understands all the challenges we are going through. Not only is God willing, He is able to grant us His grace, and in times of need, He will even give more than we ask for.

"Call unto me, and I will answer thee, and show thee great and mighty things, which thou knowest not" [Jeremiah 33:3]. Having tasted the goodness of God and His faithfulness, let us therefore not waver in faith nor rely on our own wisdom. Trust in God's providence and call upon His name; His grace is always sufficient for us.

27 SEPTEMBER.part2: Purpose of Grace - Make Us Right
27 SEPTEMBER.part4: That as sin hath reigned unto death, even so might grace reign through righteousness unto eternal life by Jesus Christ our Lord.
27 SEPTEMBER.part5:
What are the purposes of God's grace? Why did God grant us, undeserving sinners, the ability to believe in Him and follow Him? The most direct answer is found in the words of today's verse - "unto eternal life". Out of God's own good pleasure, He has chosen a remnant among the fallen human race to experience His favour, to be made right with Him and to spend eternity in His glory.

To put man as an objective in God's salvation plan would perhaps cause some to think too highly of humankind. Alas, "When I consider thy heavens, the work of thy fingers, the moon and the stars, which thou hast ordained; What is man, that thou art mindful of him? and the son of man, that thou visitest him?" [Psalm 8:3-4]. Yet it is also true that God's message to the lost world is this: "For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in Him should not perish, but have everlasting life." [John 3:16]

What should our response to God's grace then be? It should be akin to that of a criminal on death row who is given the opportunity to live on - a second chance to start all over again. There should not be any sense of self-righteousness or pride in us. Instead, we can only sing of His grace.

Why should God save man? Why should God save me? Thank God for His mercy and grace, for it is He "Who hath saved us, and called us with an holy calling, not according to our works, but according to His own purpose and grace, which was given us in Christ Jesus before the world began" [2 Timothy 1:9].
27 SEPTEMBER.part7: For thus saith the high and lofty One that inhabiteth eternity, whose name is Holy; I dwell in the high and holy place, with him also that is of a contrite and humble spirit, to revive the spirit of the humble, and to revive the heart of the contrite ones. - Isaiah 57:15

28 SEPTEMBER.part2: Purpose of Grace - To Do Right
28 SEPTEMBER.part4: That as sin hath reigned unto death, even so might grace reign through righteousness unto eternal life by Jesus Christ our Lord.
28 SEPTEMBER.part5:
God's grace transforms our lives. When Jesus shines like light into the darkness of our sin, we begin to understand God's love and have a desire to lead a life pleasing in His sight. We forsake our old ways and seek the will of God. We put off the old man and put on the new. We change to be more and more like Christ each day.

We are saved unto eternal life in God's kingdom of glory. And while waiting for the day when we see the Lord Jesus Christ face to face, we live in God's kingdom of grace. We are made right through the blood of our Lord, so that we can do right by His grace. "For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works, lest any man should boast. For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus unto good works, which God hath before ordained that we should walk in them" [Ephesians 2:8-10].

Are our lives a good testimony of God's grace? Do we bear both fruits of repentance and regeneration? Can others see Christ through us? Let us watch our thoughts, words and actions, and walk worthy of the calling wherewith we are called [Ephesians 4:1]. Every time we fail, we can come before God and confess - and He will surely forgive us through Christ. Yet every time we manage to do right, remember not to be proud, for it is also by His grace that we can do so.

Commit our ways to God, and God will grant us the wisdom and strength to lead a life that glorifies Him and edifies others.

29 SEPTEMBER.part2: Purpose of Grace - Make Known the Wisdom of God
29 SEPTEMBER.part4: That as sin hath reigned unto death, even so might grace reign through righteousness unto eternal life by Jesus Christ our Lord.
29 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Next, we go beyond the interest of man to look at God's salvation plan from His perspective. God's purpose in showing His grace through the deliverance of all who believe in Him is to make known to them His perfect wisdom.

The biblical account started with how man fell. Together with that, the world was cursed. We also read in Isaiah 14 and Ezekiel 28, how Lucifer (Satan) and many of the angels fell too because of pride. Satan sought to exalt himself above His Creator. He tempted Adam, who by his disobedience in turn corrupted the world.

The tempter and the tempted will fail because our sovereign God is always in control. He will judge all - both angels and man. He will save those who have chosen to trust in Him. Both the justice and love of God display His wisdom and glory. Satan, who thought he was equal to God, will be defeated and outwitted by God. Our Lord will judge the world, but He will also save a remnant of humankind whom He loved - not through power and violence, but through humility and love.

"To the intent that now unto the principalities and powers in heavenly places might be known by the church the manifold wisdom of God" [Ephesians 3:10], God's infinite wisdom triumphs and reigns over His creation. "O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! how unsearchable are his judgments, and his ways past finding out! For of him, and through him, and to him, are all things: to whom be glory for ever. Amen." [Romans 11:33, 36]

30 SEPTEMBER.part2: Purpose of Grace - the Fullness of Christ
30 SEPTEMBER.part4: Which is his body, the fulness of him that filleth all in all.
30 SEPTEMBER.part5:
In Ephesians 1:17-23, Paul had prayed for his readers that God would give them the spirit of wisdom and revelation in the knowledge of Christ, that their eyes would be enlightened to know the hope of God's calling, the riches of His inheritance and His power, which He had shown forth through our Lord's death on the cross, His resurrection and exaltation. Ephesians 1:22 tells us God has put all things under the feet of our Lord and gave Him to be the head over all things to the church, which is His body, which He will fill with His fullness.

It is thus God's purpose that since His salvation plan centres around the Person and work of our Lord, the church of God's people should thus show forth the bountiful grace and infinite glory of Her Saviour. The question to us His church and true believers of God's saving grace is therefore, do our lives tell of God's mercies and faithfulness? We have the indwelling of the Holy Spirit, but are we filled with the fullness of God? Or are we satisfied with the mediocre life of a nominal Christian?

In Luke 17, our Lord Jesus cleansed ten lepers who had called out to Him to show mercy upon them in their wretched condition. Jesus healed them but only one (ironically a despised Samaritan) returned to glorify God with a loud voice. To him the Lord said, "Arise, go thy way: thy faith hath made thee whole."

Dear reader, if we have truly experienced God's grace, how can we not want to live a life filled with thanksgiving and praise for Him who died for us to save us?
